candidates.name: Margaret Miles
candidates.why_elect: I was a North Shore City Councillor for 15 years prior to being a Local board member for 9 years. I have the ability to evaluate financial documents and work well with my fellow elected members to achieve results. I have lived in Upper Harbour for over 35 years.
candidates.why_stand: Having been an elected member for many years I have a strong awareness of local issues and I am willing to continue to listen and advocate for residents and communities.

candidates.name: Glen Stanton
candidates.why_elect: I have lived on the North Shore for more than 50 years so am very familiar with the area. Previously a Sales Director I now work part time as a Driver for both Knightsbridge and Mayfair Villages so am used to working with Seniors and understanding their needs.
candidates.why_stand: I will do my best to represent every constituent in Upper Harbour. However, I am aware that there are many Retirement Villages in the area and my special focus will be to give these residents a voice. If elected my pledge is to take their concerns before Council.

candidates.name: Lisa Whyte
candidates.why_elect: I have proudly represented this community in an elected position for 15 years. I have lived in other countries and communities, and use that experience to inform my decision making. If I can help with an issue I will, and if I can't I will be honest and say so.
candidates.why_stand: Upper Harbour is a great place to live, work and play. We must maintain what we care about and build for our growing and diversifying community. I have skills and experience that make me an effective community leader who gets results. Decisions made today affect the next generation.

candidates.name: Anna Atkinson
candidates.why_elect: I am a chartered accountant with 20 years experience in business. I will use my experience to ensure rates are spent effectively, efficiently and with accountability. I will provide fresh eyes to the local board as it seeks to meet the challenges of the future.
candidates.why_stand: I love where we live. I love the parks, the open spaces and the culture. I want the Local Board to protect the way of life we cherish and develop it in a sustainable way that benefits our community.

candidates.name: Uzra Casuri-Balouch
candidates.why_elect: I approach this role with an attitude of serving you. I am a Justice of Peace with 17 years experience in governance roles. I am a prudent financial manager who actively seeks your views and preferences when making decisions and proud of accountable for each one made on your behalf.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing for re-election to UHL Board because like you I call this place my home and I love it. I have worked very hard to connect with you and make a difference and I will continue to be accessible and available if given the opportunity to serve again.

candidates.name: Callum Blair
candidates.why_elect: Have served the area as an elected representative previously and have the knowledge and expertise to push Upper Harbour issues to council's attention for addressing.
candidates.why_stand: As a previous city councillor and local board member I am concerned at the reduced funding by council to the Upper Harbour. This needs addressing urgently.

candidates.name: Jaggar Bootten
candidates.why_elect: I am currently an elected member of the St John West Auckland Area Committee, board member of Cystic Fibrosis New Zealand and a medical student. On the Upper Harbour Local Board, I am very committed to listening, learning, and working with you to advocate on your behalf throughout my term.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about the challenges we face as a community. Throughout my life, I have dedicated my time to roles focused on helping other people. It concerns me that the local board lacks the passion and energy to drive meaningful change.

candidates.name: John Henry Glover
candidates.why_elect: I have a solid moral compass, understand budgets, and have strong ethics. I have a wealth experience in communications with a diverse range of people in the construction industry as a project manager. Upper Harbour is my home, so I know the landscape, community, and embrace our future.
candidates.why_stand: I decided to stand after a board meeting when I witnessed my neighbour struggle with getting sign off from the local board to complete a footpath on Gills Road, the road I grew up on. There is a real need to be an advocate for residents safety, wellbeing, and security.

candidates.name: Nicholas Mayne
candidates.why_elect: I am seeking re-election after my first term on the Local Board. I feel I have been successful in achieving a lot of what I campaigned on, in the last election; but more importantly I have learnt a lot that I want to apply to the next term.
candidates.why_stand: Upper Harbour is my backyard. I grew up here, and I am raising my kids here. As such I have seen it change over time. I want to continue to advocate, to ensure this change enhances the lives of people and the environment; while preserving the best of our heritage.

candidates.name: Jonathan Mcdonald
candidates.why_elect: I Have lived in Upper Harbour for over 25 years. I know the people, I know the places, I know the problems and I know how great it is to live here. I've run small businesses, I've been involved in leadership of community organisations both locally and nationally.
candidates.why_stand: I dislike when people say "someone should do something about X" and pass off problems as not their responsibility. I would rather solve problems than complain about them. I'm running for the Upper Harbour Local Board because I don't want to sit around and watch problems get ignored.

candidates.name: Melanie Kenrick
candidates.why_elect: I worked for over a decade as a senior mental health nurse and team leader. I am now an education charity trustee and kids' sports coach. I have the skills and experience to work effectively with the wide range of people within Kaipatiki.
candidates.why_stand: I was raised in Birkenhead, and am raising my family hear. I want to make sure what our community values is protected and enhanced. I want action on issues that could improve Kaipatiki, from the annoying lack of rubbish bins in parks and cracked paths to traffic issues.

candidates.name: Cindy Schmidt
candidates.why_elect: I work in the challenging area of health. I'm known to be efficient, effective and conscientious. This year I won a local hero award for establishing a health clinic for young people. This clinic is being modeled in mental health settings. I will bring an innovative approach to the community.
candidates.why_stand: For 19 years I have worked as a registered nurse, advocating for families and protecting communities is what I do. Protecting our unique environment is my priority. We live in an amazing place with great outdoor spaces so we must do all we can to protect our Kauri and waterways.

candidates.name: Andrew Shaw
candidates.why_elect: I bring a calm head and demeanor, a long-term view for the future and the region. I have an inclusive style of working and look forward to being an effective board member.
candidates.why_stand: I've always had an interest in planning for the future, and Intergenerational equity. Which I see as insuring my children's children have the same access to the natural environment, clean air, clean water, and safe neighborhoods as I did when I was growing up. Sounds like Local Board to me.

candidates.name: Anne-Elise Smithson
candidates.why_elect: Last election I promised greater protection of our natural environment. Kaipātiki is now leading the way for Auckland Council. I bring a head for scientific, evidence-based decision-making, and with my not-for profit experience, a heart for community. I seek re-election on my record of environmental gains, hard work and integrity.
candidates.why_stand: There's no place like Kaipātiki. Nowhere in Auckland can you experience ancient urban forest and such rich biodiversity within 10 minutes from the city. I have felt rewarded representing you but there's more work to do. I want Kaipātiki to be an even better place to live, work and play.

candidates.name: Adrian Tyler
candidates.why_elect: I do not engage in 'in-fighting', I can and do work unilaterally, I have a good understanding of social and environmental issues and I have developed a good understanding of the current problems and systems of Auckland Council over my first term on the Kaipatiki Local Board.
candidates.why_stand: I am running to campaign for and promote local democracy. The Shore Action vision is to empower local people to get things done in their own patch whether it is ecological restoration, placemaking or community house services. Local action and decision making is the most responsive and cost effective approach.

candidates.name: Frances Waaka
candidates.why_elect: I have been active in my community for over 30 years and have grown my children and now my children's children here. I want a more inclusive Kaipatiki for all families living here. I am currently the lead in building our local marae in Beach haven.
candidates.why_stand: I am honest, direct, loyal and hardworking and have a lot of aroha for my whānau and my community. I have been a leader in Kaipātiki for many years working in local sports clubs, religious groups, kapa haka, and schools.

candidates.name: John Gillon
candidates.why_elect: I have been a member of the Kaipatiki Local Board for 3 terms, most recently as Chairperson. I'm a School Board Trustee and admin of three Facebook community groups, connecting 30,000+ members of the local community. I am also past chair of the Glenfield Community Board and Bayview Community Centre.
candidates.why_stand: I love the Kaipātiki area and am devoted to our community and the North Shore way of life. I was born and raised on the Shore and live locally with my young family.

candidates.name: Paula Gillon
candidates.why_elect: I was born in Glenfield, raised in Birkenhead, attended Northcote College and live in Beach Haven—Kaipatiki through and through! I have extensive experience in representing my community in local government and I have an MPhil in Public Policy in local government and active recreation.
candidates.why_stand: Kaipatiki is an amazing place to live and I want to help make it even better! As your representative I want to continue to fight asset sales, improve our bush tracks, expand our pest-free initiatives, build a toddler-friendly playground, progress a beautiful coastal walkway and help to alleviate congestion.

candidates.name: Danielle Grant
candidates.why_elect: We have many significant projects that require leadership and good governance. I am accountable to you. My greatest strength is connecting people and projects, to ensure strong community outcomes. I bring my leadership, team focus, business acumen, open and transparent decision making to the board table.
candidates.why_stand: To build a safe, vibrant and resilient community where we can raise our families, and all feel connected. To enjoy our lifestyle, our beautiful outdoors and to support our sports clubs. To have a variety of efficient public transport options and to maintain and improve our natural environment.

candidates.name: Ann Hartley
candidates.why_elect: I have loved the chance I have had to server our community to do date. I am very proud of what we have achieved for the community.
candidates.why_stand: I am running for re-election to continue my service to our community. I see great potential for Kaipatiki and feel privileged to be standing with Kaipatiki voice, a diverse group of motivated and intelligent people who will contribute greatly to Kaipatiki's future.

candidates.name: Louis Hartley
candidates.why_elect: I have grown up here—I know this community well. My generation is increasingly aware of how the problems facing us today will impact future generations. I will do my best to take action to address the problems facing Kaipātiki. Kaipātiki local board needs a vision, not a placeholder.
candidates.why_stand: I am running for Kaipātiki local board because youth involvement in politics is plummeting. I want to bring a voice to Kaipātiki that represents tomorrow. I feel comfortable running with Kaipātiki Voice because it's a diverse and capable team who represent all of Kaipātiki.

candidates.name: Jesse Jensen
candidates.why_elect: I have a background in fundraising and activism. I have spent the past 3 years actively lobbying the council to provide more public spaces for artists in Auckland. I will be a staunch advocate for minorities and marginalized groups in our community.
candidates.why_stand: I was born here, I am 33. I am from Beach Haven and grew up hard. I am now a self-employed artist and believe my unique life experiences will help me to negotiate with council to achieve better outcomes for our community. Real Values, Real Solutions.

candidates.name: John Wood
candidates.why_elect: I have a strong commitment to fix the major problems affecting the local area and Auckland. My extensive management experience, supported by formal qualifications in Business and Dispute Resolution enable me to understand the important issues; strongly advocate and debate initiatives; and push for resolution, seeking compromise when necessary.
candidates.why_stand: Local government responses to reduce carbon emissions have been poor. With 40% of Auckland's emissions due to transport (and predominantly car usage) a change to the status quo will be difficult, but necessary. I will bring effective, brave leadership to have the challenging conversations needed to promote change.

candidates.name: Gavin Busch
candidates.why_elect: I can bring my skills and background of strong community involvement to help the board. I am prepared to listen to all opinions, weigh the arguments and stick to the decisions the board makes.
candidates.why_stand: For too long our area has been help back, we have lacked the support of council officers and the council in general who have chosen to work with other boards that have demonstrated a desire to work cooperatively and without prejudice. We deserve better.

candidates.name: Paul Cornish
candidates.why_elect: 25 years in the community creates a strong sense of identity. I am highly driven, passionate about my causes and a strong believer in the democratic process making me a good collaborator. Professionally trained as an accountant, I would bring dignity to office and am eager to make a contribution.
candidates.why_stand: I have invested my time heavily in supporting community groups and with this experience believe that I can make a contribution at a broader level. Additionally, I am concerned about the loss of public space due to housing intensification and seek influence to avoid degradation of our invaluable open spaces.

candidates.name: Trish Deans
candidates.why_elect: My experience as an Assistant Principal in secondary school was invaluable. I introduced a restorative pastoral care system changed students attitudes as they learnt to solve a problem. I then completed studies in Dispute Resolution, and through these experiences I learnt the value of working alongside a community.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing as a candidate for the Local Board as I passionately believe that this Local Board area has a community that cares and wants sensible solutions. I will advocate effectively to deliver the resources needed to provide the solutions.

candidates.name: Donald Horsburgh
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in both public and private sectors, with 7 years at 10 Downing Street, and roles in senior management. I have successfully managed large, complex programmes of work and positively resolve conflicting views. I have the skills, vision and experience to get more done for the entire community.
candidates.why_stand: I was brought up on the east coast of Scotland I have a connection with the sea. I love the diverse nature of the peninsula—from Devonport to the hustle and bustle of Takapuna with its shops, restaurants and theatres. The stunning views from Castor Bay and Milford Marina.

candidates.name: Jenn Mckenzie
candidates.why_elect: I am community minded and have held various leadership positions in many Non-Profit Organisations including Rotary. As a Brand Manager I have strong strategic and analytical skills and personal connections. I am passionate and have the experience to move projects forward.
candidates.why_stand: I am young (31) and bring a diverse perspective to local issues. I am community minded with strong strategic and leadership skills. The decisions we make today will leave a legacy. I want to continue the strong work I have already started on the Board.

candidates.name: Iain Rea
candidates.why_elect: Through the coordination of community consultation, I've learnt how effective and constructive change can be made. This involved a large development, action at court level, and the first application of the Unitary Plan. I listen and seek differing views for solutions. I will heed those views and stand-up for them.
candidates.why_stand: It would continue existing community work. I care about how we create a better, shared future. I've learnt no individual or agency has all the answers and positive change comes from constructive dialogue. Council shouldn't just hear the ideas from the community, it needs to put that experience to use.

candidates.name: Ian Revell
candidates.why_elect: My family have been resident here for over 100 years, and I was honoured to be elected to Parliament as a local National MP for 9 years, gaining enormous experience in dealing with a myriad of local issues and working closely with Council. I am ready to give back.
candidates.why_stand: The Board needs an injection of forward thinking and experienced people committed to improving the well being and the vibrancy of our delightful City. Stream and beach (storm) water quality is a pressing and urgent issue, and probably the most complex to solve. New solutions are needed.

candidates.name: Dorothea Akenese Scanlan
candidates.why_elect: I've lived here for a few years. As a woman it offers safety security and stability with the facilities that we have access to. I'm a member of the local Just workout gym, Takapuna Aquatic centre and local library... political research, law studies, updating as a qualified experienced Legal Executive.
candidates.why_stand: I believe our city could do with a boost. It is boring according to my discussions with the younger generation in our local area that standing for Devonport-Takapuna for Local Board. They suggested with respect that the old white men from cave dark ages sitting in the Council must go.

candidates.name: Michael Sheehy
candidates.why_elect: I am a practical hands and results driven person with a strong business background—33 yrs running my own business. I am appalled at the procrastination that has gone on. Team George Wood will make things happen and move to the next issue to resolve. We're action orientated.
candidates.why_stand: I'm completing 3 yrs on the D-T board and feel I should get things started completed. We have developed and implemented the local board plan and need to get thing done. We are a can do team at Team George Wood.

candidates.name: Toni Van Tonder
candidates.why_elect: I understand where our Local Board needs to improve and I know that I can make a difference; I'm talking about better communication, collaboration and applying a future focus. I bring excellent relationships to this role, and have a track record for hard work and a passion for our area.
candidates.why_stand: I understand the Local Board environment well. There's a palpable mood for change and we need a departure from combative to collaborative governance. I'm running because I have a future focus and can add value, especially in supporting environmental and community outcomes that create healthier places to live.

candidates.name: George Wood
candidates.why_elect: I am well known as a strong team player. Had nine years as mayor of the former North Shore City council and six years as a councillor on the Auckland Council representing the North Shore ward. Currently I am the chairman of the Devonport-Takapuna Local Board. Only Sunnynook/Forrest Hill candidate.
candidates.why_stand: I am experienced and have a lot of knowledge and skills at running meetings. I'm able to bring people together and form a strong team. My team had three members in the last term on the Devonport-Takapuna Local Board. We made a sound contribution and therefore are standing again.

candidates.name: Aidan Bennett
candidates.why_elect: I am recognised as being a leader in our community. I understand the importance of building relationships to achieve results. I will lead change in the way the DTLB operates and works for the community, focusing on communication, collaboration, building respect and generally applying a fresh approach. That's well overdue.
candidates.why_stand: I strongly believe there needs to be a change in the way the local board operates. We need people less focused on politics and more on achieving for our community. Building a better future. I want to be a leader of that positive change for the good of our community.

candidates.name: John Riddell
candidates.why_elect: I am a Health and safety consultant, my training and experience allows me to understand the root cause of issues and problems and solve them quickly, efficiently and safely. I am approachable, keen to listen and have the proven experience and strength to advocate on your behalf.
candidates.why_stand: I am a Westie, the Henderson Massey Local Board area is large and diverse however people do not feel connected. I have lived and worked in most parts of the area and proud of the area and want to see others enjoy the variety of experiences the area offers.

candidates.name: Paula Bold-Wilson
candidates.why_elect: I have had the privilege of serving this community for the past 20 years, in a range of management, and governance roles. These experiences have given me insight into the difficulties families experience, and enabled me to implement strategic measures to effectively bring about positive change.
candidates.why_stand: I have a big heart for the west, especially since my children were born and raised here. One of the characteristics I love about our community, is the diverse group of people who call West home—this is something I'm extremely proud of.

candidates.name: Brenda Brady
candidates.why_elect: I am fair and open minded and my commitment is to all of our community. I have a very good understanding of the technical and financial requirements of the role and as a social practitioner a deep understanding of social and cultural needs. I work hard as your elected member.
candidates.why_stand: I love my community and I believe the West is a wonderful place to live and bring up a family. I am very committed to our community and I recognise many who live here work very hard and yet have few luxuries in their life.

candidates.name: Daniel Eisenhut
candidates.why_elect: I am not a past politician, I am not swayed by a preconceived political ideology, what I am is a fresh pair of eyes and full of enthusiasm, I will approach issues with a renewed vigour with the community outcome and impact my first priority. I am you.
candidates.why_stand: I am actively involved in the Te Atatu Peninsula community mainly through sports clubs and my 2 sons Eli (5) and Grayson (2). I have lived in the North for 10+ years. I will be approachable, accessible and visible for the community I represent.

candidates.name: Warren William Flaunty
candidates.why_elect: Unprecedented growth is occurring in Henderson-Massey Local Board area which needs to be matched with new infrastructure and facilities. My wealth of intellectual knowledge with be extremely helpful in ensuring that the issues of this growth are addressed.
candidates.why_stand: As can be seen from my candidate information I have been extremely active in my community for over 40 years. Over this time I have developed a wealth of intellectual knowledge to ensure all sectors of the community continue to be well represented on Auckland Council.

candidates.name: Will Flavell
candidates.why_elect: My family and I have lived in West Auckland for over 15 years. I have been elected to the Henderson-Massey Local Board for two terms so have good governance experience. I am also currently the Head of Māori Studies at Rutherford College in Te Atatū Peninsula.
candidates.why_stand: I was first elected in 2013. Therefore, I want to continue to advocate for West Auckland. I love the diversity and richness of our people and the beautiful environment that we all share. I believe in the potential of our community.

candidates.name: Rebecca George-Koteka
candidates.why_elect: I am passionate about empowered communities. When our families and communities are empowered to address local issues, to have a voice, to understand what processes are and what they look like and how local body and government decisions affect them, they can then make informed decisions.
candidates.why_stand: I have served my community for the past 20 years as a youth worker, in community development, facilities management, managing an empowering women's programme, events management, facilitation, leadership development and more. As a Pacific Woman I am standing with the support of all friends and family.

candidates.name: Matt Grey
candidates.why_elect: With twenty years' experience in youth development I know what kind environment is needed to help young people thrive. I have completed my Masters in Community Safety, gaining insight into moving our town centres forward. In all my work I am committed to making a difference in my community.
candidates.why_stand: I'm born and raised here, so this isn't a job for me. I see the potential we have of being a thriving, connected, diverse and distinct part of Auckland. I want to raise my kids in a community that is safe, and gives them the best chances in life.

candidates.name: Shane Henderson
candidates.why_elect: I grew up here, and live here in with my young family. I have served as chair of the Henderson-Massey Local Board, worked with charities and community groups as a lawyer here, and led in projects to make the West a better place to live.
candidates.why_stand: I love the West, and I am standing to make this a place where every young Westie gets fair opportunities to thrive. I have a new vision for West Auckland, where housing opportunities link with local high-quality jobs and excellent public transport for modern town centres.

candidates.name: Murali Kumar
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in NZ for more than 20 years and worked with central and local government for many years. My government experience focussed on community development across diverse communities, having supported and developed many groups and organisations. I have also held Management roles with Auckland Council.
candidates.why_stand: Auckland is a growing diverse city. I believe there is an opportunity for diverse representation and leadership in Henderson-Massey. I am particularly keen to contribute to social, economic and environmental outcomes in my local board area. I also aspire to be a strong voice for our vibrant communities.

candidates.name: Brooke Loader
candidates.why_elect: I live in the West with my family, run my own law firm here, am committed to serving our community through a number of community groups and want to get the best for the West.
candidates.why_stand: I am proud to be bringing my family up in West Auckland and I love it here. I care for our community and want Henderson-Massey to be the best place for our families and communities to live, work and play.

candidates.name: Ingrid Papau
candidates.why_elect: As a small business owner, mother, and Te Atatu resident, I have a passion for creating community spirit out West. Running for council is just one way to achieve this—I started a neighbourhood support group, have organised street BBQs and children's community events, volunteer, and advocate in the community.
candidates.why_stand: I care about the people in my community. I want to advocate on their behalf and speak-out for more than the crumbs for my area. I love the West; it's my home. For too long West Auckland has received less than its central neighbours, and we deserve our fair share.

candidates.name: Sandra Coney
candidates.why_elect: I have had experience in the regional council, council and local board so I know how local government works and how to get things to happen. I have lived all my life in the West and I have strong connections with the community.
candidates.why_stand: I am committed to protecting the things that are precious about Waitakere, our green areas and our heritage, natural and historic. We have legislation that says our area is of national significance so we have to protect it for future generations.

candidates.name: Tony Hartnett
candidates.why_elect: I have career experience in environmental and energy planning in NZ and Canada. I understand the workings and politics of local and central government. I continue to work with people at community level. I am able to work with people on committees to translate policy ideas into budgets and actions.
candidates.why_stand: I have lived here for thirty years and love the Waitakere Ranges. I have served on the New Lynn Community Board. I helped Auckland Council to declare a climate emergency. I want to make progress on a local and Auckland Climate Action plan, before it is too late.

candidates.name: Greg Presland
candidates.why_elect: As well as my political experience I have practised law out west for 30 years and have helped people through stressful times. I have also been heavily involved with local community organisations and I know how wonderful and constructive local groups can be.
candidates.why_stand: I am the current chair and have served three terms. The job is challenging and exhilarating. I have lived here for 30 years and my kids were born here. The area and the people are magnificent. But there are many challenges and I want to make the west even better.

candidates.name: Mark Roberts
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Titirangi for 36 years, love the Waitakere Ranges and our local communities. A Chartered Accountant and Commercial Pilot I have worked most of the last 25 years as Company Director and Chief Executive. I will bring governance, management, financial skills and passion to the role.
candidates.why_stand: I am appreciative of the opportunities and lifestyle afforded my family by the wonderful Waitakere Ranges area. I see issues within the area that need to be addressed and want to make a contribution. I now have the time, energy and skill set to do this.

candidates.name: Michelle Wineera
candidates.why_elect: I love the community I live in and have loads of experience in management, people skills and a natural tendency to care for the environment.
candidates.why_stand: I am fortunate to live in the most naturally beautiful environment in Auckland. The Waitakere community are warm and friendly, innovative and creative and we really do care about our native bush which we all need to protect for our future generations to come.

candidates.before_politics: Manager comm dev and env group
candidates.name: Mark Allen
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in and with local government for 30 years in a variety of roles. So I know how the beast works and doesn't. So I know the tricks, I know what needs to done, when to get things happening and I am independent.
candidates.why_stand: I love our area. Raised in Laingholm, built our house at Te Henga and raised three great boys in our fabulous local schools. I believe we need to get the local back into local government in Auckland. More decision making at the local board and in the local community.

candidates.name: Sue Daly
candidates.why_elect: I've lived here for more than forty years, raised a family and now have grandchildren in the schools. I've started new businesses and managed old ones, and I've helped build community facilities and served on various trusts. I have never lost my passion for this island.
candidates.why_stand: I think we have extremely important times ahead. We need to make sure that every decision we make considers climate change and its potential ramifications. This means understanding our ecological footprint and building resilience and sustainability into everything we do.

candidates.name: Valmaine Toki
candidates.why_elect: As tangata whenua I have a responsibility, as kaitiaki, to ensure the motu is maintained sustainably for future generations. In addition, I have the requisite skill set and experience to achieve this.
candidates.why_stand: Aotea, Great Barrier Island is unique. I am running to protect and help ensure Aotea remains pristine. For example, stopping the marine dumping of sludge within our waters. This is an important issue the community have come together to fight.

candidates.name: Bob Upchurch
candidates.why_elect: I have lived on Waiheke for over forty years so have a sound knowledge of Waiheke's needs. Having spent the past three years on the Local Board, I am well up to speed on what is required to achieve outcomes in Council for the benefit of our community.
candidates.why_stand: As a long time local, and a retired teacher, I have time to put back into the community which has served me and my family very well. I am standing again to ensure some of the issues we have worked on over the past three years reach completion.

candidates.name: Kathy Voyles
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in many diverse settings, served on boards on Waiheke and overseas. My skills are in communicating, listening, negotiating and moving forward. I believe in 'see it, say it and sort it'. I do the work and make things happen.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing for Waiheke Local Board to represent the large number of islanders who strive everyday to make this island sustainable, biodiverse, healthy and safe. I will strive to ensure our community has the tools to look after each other and move forward in a kind and compassionate way.

candidates.name: David John Baigent
candidates.why_elect: I am a former print journalist and trainer in management communication. This means I can know to listen for what citizens really want and then turn that into succinct communication for them to higher authorities—Auckland Council, Auckland Transport.
candidates.why_stand: Waiheke is a unique place of caring people and that is why I love living here. That is why I want to serve it by running for election to its local board. We need a strong voice to the outside world for our values.

candidates.name: Alexandra Bonham
candidates.why_elect: I know Auckland well. I was a walking tour guide here and this led me to study the role of play in Auckland's urban ecology for my PhD. My research covers law, urban planning, innovation, play, psychology, the arts. I'm really interested, I care and I'm hard-working, friendly, and quick..
candidates.why_stand: I was asked by a women I deeply respect to consider doing so. I have long been an advocate for children and youth to have access to play. As the city evolves I feel strongly that we need to set aside space for nature, for people, for quality of life.

candidates.name: Tadhg Tim Stopford
candidates.why_elect: I'm a kiwi. Luckily I've been able to see the world too, and I'm a big reader. So, I reckon I have a good idea about some of the things we are doing well, not so well, and not at all. My professional networks are wide, and my ethics good.
candidates.why_stand: We, and our kids, face trouble in housing, economy, climate, food security, job security, world peace even. I'd like to help us move beyond tinkering at the edges to actually changing the models which are causing us grief. "We don't have money, so we have to think"—Lord Rutherford.

candidates.name: Glenda Fryer
candidates.why_elect: I served as an Auckland City Councillor for nine years including Chair of its Planning Committee, am a current Local Board member, leading in Parks and local economic development. I listen and know how to get things done. I'll call CCOs to account in the complex system of Auckland Council.
candidates.why_stand: I feel blessed to live in Waitemata. We have a duty to improve our environment and nurture our community. I will give my heart and vision to grasp and tackle the huge issues of population growth, housing, transport, and climate change. I'll work hard creating an inclusive and caring community.

candidates.name: Graeme Gunthorp
candidates.why_elect: I'm enthusiastic and excited, as well as experienced enough to deliver on my promises. I have great management experience, understand how to run complex operations, and will always listen to the community for new ideas.
candidates.why_stand: I love seeing cities work efficiently, and I see so many opportunities to make Auckland the most liveable, enjoyable and incredible city in the world. I'll focus on the transport network, public spaces, events and utilities, and I will give everything I have to make it happen.

candidates.name: Allan Matson
candidates.why_elect: I've spent years trying to protect heritage buildings, and I think there is a need amongst those elected for greater understanding of the built environment. Having been on various elected bodies before, I am familiar with getting items on agendas, gathering the necessary information and helping to make informed decisions.
candidates.why_stand: I don't want Auckland's future growth to be characterised by ugly development, and so I'm running because I think an elected position would provide the opportunity to bring a greater sensibility to issues around the built environment, in particular the retention of some of the city's architectural heritage and character.

candidates.name: Will Maxwell-Steele
candidates.why_elect: I've lived in the Waitemata Local Board area for almost all of my adult life. I have seen far too much waste and poor planning. Being self employed, I know the value of a dollar and will question things that don't seem right.
candidates.why_stand: I believe Auckland is an amazing city and that we need to keep it that way.

candidates.name: Keith Mcconnell
candidates.why_elect: Three reasons. I will ask the difficult questions and keep asking them until I get a satisfactory answer. I have no allegiances to either a party or special causes so can judge issues on their merits. I am prepared to speak out on things that aren't working.
candidates.why_stand: I want to make a difference by using my time, skills and experience to significantly improve the standard of the services provided to residents and businesses by Council and Auckland Transport so that our area retains its standing as a top class area to work and live.

candidates.name: Richard Northey
candidates.why_elect: I have years of experience and achievement of being an effective elected representative and of chairing successful community organisations such as the Auckland Community Housing Trust, the Problem Gambling Foundation and the Auckland District Council of Social Services.
candidates.why_stand: I want to do what I can to accomplish policies and services for a higher quality of life and greater fairness and opportunity for all Aucklanders.

candidates.name: Julie Sandilands
candidates.why_elect: I am practical, passionate and love my community. I am a local business owner, a writer and a sustainability expert, with qualifications in engineering, business and science. I am committed to great outcomes for Waitematā.
candidates.why_stand: I want everyone to get the best out of Waitematā.

candidates.name: Reuben Shadbolt
candidates.why_elect: I am more like you working people of Auckland than those I stand against and to hopefully replace in this election. I look and listen with my eyes and ears but see and hear with my heart and mind for only then the truth i will find for the people.
candidates.why_stand: Like many I have become disillusioned with councils inability to collectively do what's best for Auckland as one big community. It's not just that I want to be a politician, more that I want to be around politicians so i can report back to our city on what's going on.

candidates.name: Aadil Basha
candidates.why_elect: I bring a firm approach towards funding, my business experience and financial background, am good at crunching numbers and data analysis, stop unwarranted, unnecessary spending and channel them to the most important matters of priority for my community and ward.
candidates.why_stand: Whau has been my home now for several years, I love my ward, am passionate about my community and community services, I would like to be a fresh positive voice, harnessing its strengths. I'm a person of vision, action and perseverance. It would be my privilege to serve you.

candidates.name: Kay Thomas
candidates.why_elect: My experiences as a secondary teacher in multicultural secondary schools for over 30 years and as a voluntary worker in New Lynn have given me a range of management, governance and communication skills. I am hard working, have integrity and compassion and can represent diverse points of view.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing for the Whau Local Board because I am concerned about what the future holds for its citizens, especially young people. Working in the voluntary sector has made me aware of issues faced by the people in the area, such as poverty and homelessness.

candidates.name: Lawrence Watt
candidates.why_elect: I was brought up in Green Bay, where my parents were teachers. I have wider experience, working for central Government, the media, UNICEF and others. I am a people person who believes all people—all ages and races—and the environment—are important. I'm good at meetings.
candidates.why_stand: I believe I have something to contribute—arising from professional and Governance experience. I want to see growth managed, for both people and the environment. The Devil is in the detail here. I want the Whau to retain being a good place to live, while becoming more exciting.

candidates.name: Susan Zhu
candidates.why_elect: I am a lawyer with good understanding on how central and local government works, experienced in governance roles and have deep connections with the wider local communities, particularly the diverse communities in Whau.
candidates.why_stand: I am the current elected member and the Deputy Chairperson of the Whau Local Board since 2013. Recently, the Whau Local Board made significant milestones in securing Whau swimming pool, Avondale regeneration, Ethnic and Pacific People's Plans etc.  I would like to have opportunity to ensure those projects are realised.

candidates.name: Catherine Farmer
candidates.why_elect: Prior to amalgamation in 2010 I was elected to the Avondale Community Board. During that time I supported a grassroots campaign to schedule and save the Rosebank heritage Oak and Pohutukawa trees. I continue to maintain active connections with many community of interest groups over many years.
candidates.why_stand: I am motivated to stand for election because I know that there are many ways that we can improve our experience of living in Whau. I grew up in Avondale, attended the local schools and still live here. In Whau we deserve better facilities and I will advocate for them.

candidates.name: Jessamine Fraser
candidates.why_elect: As an architect with my own practice, and an architectural design tutor, I have an expert understanding of urban and housing issues, and experience working with diverse groups and leading interdisciplinary teams solving complex problems.
candidates.why_stand: The Whau is an exciting area with a lot of potential, and I want to work with our communities to create a sustainable and vibrant future for all of us.

candidates.name: Warwick Frederikson
candidates.why_elect: I have been a businessman for many years in a variety of businesses. Working in supermarket management, I have a lot of experience with people with a lot of training. I have also run programs looking after unemployed. I believe that Independents offer far more than Party candidates.
candidates.why_stand: The Whau area has a character all of its own. From the classic Westie image to the new cosmopolitan business and transport hub. I have lived through it all and strongly believe that we are not doing enough to make the area boom. Far too much politics.

candidates.name: Warren Piper
candidates.why_elect: I'm a local resident living in New Lynn, and as such, I face many of the issues local residents have here. I am the current Chairperson of the New Lynn Business Association and have a proven track record of strong governance and financial management.
candidates.why_stand: I believe we need to make the Board more accountable to the interests of the community, and rise above party politics. As an independent with a fresh perspective, I can work with anyone who wants to help build a better future for all of us.

candidates.name: Jessica Rose
candidates.why_elect: I have a good amount of professional experience, as well as community development and advocacy from a grassroots level. I know that it's a long game to secure good outcomes in a local context, and I also know that a successful board rests on its ability to negotiate.
candidates.why_stand: I'm running because I live in the area and I want to improve my local community. I also want to improve knowledge ('demystify'), and access to democracy so that we can have good representation on a board. One that reflects the voice of the people it represents, year on year.

candidates.name: Fasitua Amosa
candidates.why_elect: I am personable and approachable and as a professional actor, my art form has given me the ability to really empathize with a variety of people and their situations. I went to school in the area and spent much of my life here and want to see the area improve.
candidates.why_stand: When I got my matai title one of the things that was impressed on me was that it meant I am called to serve. Whau is a rad area and I want to see young, progressive, professional Polynesians like myself have a voice and representation at the decision making table.

candidates.name: Mike Finlayson
candidates.why_elect: I'm a good listener and gather a wealth of information from the many community engagements I participate in. I see opportunity and push hard for the best solutions. In the last three years I have worked extensively with the community to achieve great results in flood and environmental protection.
candidates.why_stand: To help our community better protect the environment (water, native species, marine ecosystems etc) simultaneously creating employment opportunities in the Far North. Helping to build better democratic engagement so communities aren't just 'consulted', they would be integral in the development of policies and projects that would benefit us all.

candidates.name: Penny Smart
candidates.why_elect: Northland is home for me and a region that I care deeply about, having lived here all my life, raised a family and run a business here. I have current and previous governance experience and consider myself to be very approachable, diligent, honest and to have integrity.
candidates.why_stand: Northland's environmental sustainability and enhancement are core reasons for me standing for the Regional Council. I am also very focused on the Kaipara as I believe that there is untapped potential for economic, cultural, social and environmental development and improvement. Collaboration is key for me.

candidates.name: Jocelyn Yeoman
candidates.why_elect: Open, honest, transparent communications and collaboration are the cornerstones of my career. I've worked full-time for the community as a regional councillor, including as a hearing commissioner on the proposed regional plan. I ensure the communities concerns are at the heart of what I do.
candidates.why_stand: I'm passionate about Northland and developing a resilient, prosperous region for future generations to continue to live, work and play here.

candidates.name: John Bain
candidates.why_elect: I have experience of the politics on local government and have made sound friends while delivering good results to all parts of NRC policy. I can make the hard decisions and still talk to any colleague may not agree with me. My constituents can be sure I represent them well.
candidates.why_stand: I have a few targets I want to achieve with the roads, water and maintaining good management policies. I still have a lot to contribute with knowledge I have gained over the last couple of terms. I ask for the votes to complete this work.

candidates.name: Jack Craw
candidates.why_elect: I am a proud local that is highly experienced in management and governance in science, conservation, resource management and regional government. I am the former Biosecurity Manager for Auckland Region and currently operate an environmental and biosecurity consultancy throughout NZ and the Pacific.
candidates.why_stand: Northland must adapt rapidly to meet massive environmental challenges and save ratepayers future financial losses. We need a strong proponent for getting the North's rivers swimmable again, more proactive planning for the emerging climate emergency, and integrated transportation system. I am also an expert on kauri dieback and biosecurity.

candidates.name: Jeroen Jongejans
candidates.why_elect: I have been fortunate to have been in many governance positions on a local, regional and national level—from Conservation Board, a Whangarei Councillor, national tourism boards, numerous local organisations for over 30 years—own Dive! Tutukaka and learned many lessons to be a very effective representative for the community.
candidates.why_stand: Northland has been good for me, I want to give back and help to pass on an environment better than when I arrived 40 years ago—others before us have tried their best—now it is our turn—give the best back that we can!

candidates.name: Amy Macdonald
candidates.why_elect: I am a freshwater ecologist, with over a decade of experience working in conservation and environmental management. My professional background and personal values mean I can effectively represent the voices and values of our people, and future generations, in council.
candidates.why_stand: I am a mother to three young children, I want to help ensure future generations inherit healthy land and waterways so they can enjoy their natural environment and live a good life.

candidates.name: Colin Peter Thew
candidates.why_elect: I've had two terms previously in local government, facilitating close links between communities and council. My environmental management degree provides a perfect foundation for regional council governance. I am dedicated in everything I do, honest and a good communicator.
candidates.why_stand: On moving to Northland six years ago, I quickly fell in love with the region, and decided this is where I want to stay. I feel this is the right time to put my hat back in the ring, and re-enter local governance.

candidates.name: Maggie Buxton
candidates.why_elect: For over 25 years I have worked in NZ and globally supporting people, organisations and projects in the environmental, social and political spheres. I have experience in project management, facilitation and governance, a PhD in Creative Technology (AUT) and an MSc in Organisational Development (Sheffield Business School). I listen!
candidates.why_stand: I am standing to make a positive difference to a region that I love! I want clean rivers, a strong economy and engaged communities. I have the unique set of skills and experience make this happen. I will work hard to leave a positive legacy for the future.

candidates.name: Paul Dimery
candidates.why_elect: I have had the honour and privilege of being the elected member for the last six years. I was in the NZ Police for 35 years. I was the Area Commander for Whangarei/Kaipara for 12.5 years. I have strong ethics and integrity and I work for the community.
candidates.why_stand: Northland is one of the most beautiful regions in the world. I have been privileged to work and live in an environment that has brought me much happiness and a sense of fulfillment. I want my grandchildren to enjoy the natural resources as much I have.

candidates.name: David Lourie
candidates.why_elect: I understand the issues, the players and their ideologies and motives, and the concerns of the public. What I don't understand I can research. I can discern fact from fantasy and information from disinformation. That is a good basis for the role of governance.
candidates.why_stand: I have been involved in many submission and hearing processes and a few campaigns. There have been elements within council that obstruct good central government legislation, policy statements and stonewall public input, the latest being ignoring public concern over the release of GMOs. Better to be sitting at the table.

candidates.name: Rick Stolwerk
candidates.why_elect: Having been involved on school, regional and national boards I believe I have the governance experience to move this region forward. I see my role in the next term of council as growing the interconnection between community, economy and environment by building on local community initiatives already underway.
candidates.why_stand: Having lived at my amazing local beach for 41 years, I believe that I understand the issues that this area faces; in particular pest management, coastal flooding and coastal water quality. Having been involved in surf life saving for this period I have seen the devastating changes to the coast.

candidates.name: Clyde Graf
candidates.why_elect: To make a good council representative, a person must have courage and determination. In Council, it is staff that often drive the agenda, and unfortunately most councillors sit back and do little to challenge that bureaucratic direction when needed. My track record shows I work for the people, not staff.
candidates.why_stand: I have spent the last 21 years interviewing, and listening to community members while filming and producing wildlife and environmental documentaries. I enjoy hearing about the issues that matter to people and I enjoy representing those people and their communities, offering a voice on their behalf.

candidates.name: Dal Minogue
candidates.why_elect: Firstly, I regard it as a privilege to represent the Thames-Coromandel ward and take the duties that arise seriously. Secondly, I always do my best to capture the genuine feelings of people. Thirdly, I adopt an honest, straight forward leadership style when representing those in Council.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about improving and protecting our environment while allowing for the continued economic expansion of our economy. I am passionate about finding smart, intelligent, innovative ways to do this because if we don't, none of us will win.

candidates.name: Denis Tegg
candidates.why_elect: As a (retired) lawyer and community campaigner I have the requisite knowledge experience and vision. eg. as a private citizen I initiated the successful Thames public bus service, and 20 years ago, I proposed a law which still protects many Coromandel beaches and forests from mining.
candidates.why_stand: I'm standing for Waikato Regional Council because I want our children to inherit a livable and prosperous planet. We may fail to do that unless we reduce emissions by 50% within 10 years. This is a climate crisis and regional council must lead with urgent action.

candidates.name: Keith Holmes
candidates.why_elect: I understand the importance of the RMA and Governance. The RMA demands a Healthy Environment, Vibrant Communities and a Strong Economy. The strong Economy has been neglected, and without "serious regenerative" money, our ambitions Environmentally and Socially will stall and fail.
candidates.why_stand: Waikato Region lacks good governance. Governance is about visionary leadership to set good policy for staff to carry out Rates and Compliance costs are rising unaffordably and exponentially. It is a Local Govt. and Govt. issue and needs to be addressed pragmatically, not bypassed.

candidates.name: Pamela Storey
candidates.why_elect: As a 23-year resident of the Waikato constituency bringing 18+ years of governance experience, alongside corporate, non-profit, and small business leadership, I also bring an empathy and engagement with rural communities across our region. I am a proud food producer and community leader committed to the Mighty Waikato.
candidates.why_stand: As a leader of many such initiatives over a number of years, I believe, whole-heartedly, in community led change. With broad experience and long-term regional commitment, now is the right time to bring my unique skill set and region-wide network to provide a strong voice for our rural communities.

candidates.name: Richard Gee
candidates.why_elect: I get action, my involvement by listening then promoting ideas achieves results in communities, business, and committees. My leadership is open, transparent, and direct focussed on what is best for my communities. I care about the Waikato region and Tuakau and districts in the north Waikato.
candidates.why_stand: I want to make a difference and have the voice of the people in Waikato heard louder to ensure the northern waikato gets more say in regional development to get a better understanding of what the regional council actually does and to use the knowledge of the communities more.

candidates.name: Fred Lichtwark
candidates.why_elect: I manage an award-winning group that's planted 2 million native trees and I'm a Waikato Regional Councillor, with a background in farming and fishing. My experience proves working with communities can be a win, win; we can reduce rates and enjoy a healthy, resilient environment and economy.
candidates.why_stand: I'm committed to value for money, sustainable farming and clean water—we deserve clean rivers, lakes and harbours and working together we can achieve this in 20 years not 100 years.

candidates.name: Tara Jesperson
candidates.why_elect: I may not have the first-hand knowledge and experience of other candidates but what I have is passion and enthusiasm. I grew up in the country with a fisherman father so have some understanding of how things work and have a constant desire to learn more and help others.
candidates.why_stand: I have always felt drawn to protecting the environment and instantly fell in love with the Waikato when I moved here in 2015. I want to do all I can to keep her beautiful while making sure primary industries are looked after and operate sustainably.

candidates.name: Bill Cox
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in the Te Aroha district for 58 yrs farming land drainage waste management contracting for farmers frontera wallace Corp councils and as a McKenzie friend helping people the the courts as well as serving on the Thames valley drainage board.

candidates.name: Stu Husband
candidates.why_elect: Over the last 6 years I have enjoyed the challenges of representing my Constituents. I am a passionate advocate who isn't afraid to speak out about issues facing the community. With my communication, enthusiasm and influencing skills I have shown I have these qualities and more to offer the Region.
candidates.why_stand: To continue advocating for my constituents. It takes time to make a difference, build up networks and see benefits. I have a thorough understanding of how the processes work, considerable experience in issues that matter to ratepayers and am actively involved in seeking change for a more efficiently run Council.

candidates.name: Kathy White
candidates.why_elect: I moved to Taupō when my father started DSIR's freshwater ecology laboratory here in the early 1970s. I'm a researcher and writer who has written submissions for animal protection and environmental groups. I'm proud to be the current Chair of the Environmental and Services Performance Committee for Waikato Regional Council.
candidates.why_stand: I believe in compassionate conservation. I want our wildlife, ecosystems and food-chain to be healthy and I want people in our communities to be able to safely use and appreciate our outdoor spaces. I'm concerned about the way we use a variety of contaminants in our environment.

candidates.name: Bernhard Chrustowski
candidates.why_elect: Successful business man with proven financial stewardship skills that allowed me to retire to Taupō in 2001. While serving as Taupō District councillor our Council achieved the highest Standard and Poor's credit rating for NZ councils. Extensive environmental experience as a RMA commissioner. Dedicated community volunteer.
candidates.why_stand: My grandchildren: I don't want to leave their generation's future to fate when today we have the means to protect it. We have a moral obligation to act now. I want to be part of the solution and be able to influence the future in a positive way.

candidates.name: Alana Delich
candidates.why_elect: As a Mum and Ecologist who grew up on a farm I have a balanced perspective. I have lived in the Taupō-Rotorua constituency my whole working life, and have been on the ground throughout our rohe, in conservation, geothermal and water monitoring roles. I know the issues we face.
candidates.why_stand: I put my name forward for Waikato Regional Council because I love where I live, and want to see it managed in the best possible way for our future generations. I believe our area deserves to be represented by someone who cares about a broad range of issues.

candidates.name: Jennifer Nickel
candidates.why_elect: I'm a sponge for learning, fascinated by other points of view and different ways of doing things. The scientist in me evaluates critically, wants to address the root cause of issues and invites cooperation to solve them. Also, I have good insight into what's important to individuals, businesses and councils.
candidates.why_stand: As a sustainability professional my heart lies in making a positive impact on a larger scale for future generations—on the systems we live in. I love the Waikato and believe we can still do better to honour the environment and the people.

candidates.name: Angela Strange
candidates.why_elect: I love talking with people and listening to their passions, concerns and frustrations. I work collaboratively with others and believe we are stronger together. All of my jobs have had people at the heart—and being a regional councillor is no different.
candidates.why_stand: The Waikato region is a great place to live, work, and raise a family. A healthy environment lays the foundation for connected communities and therefore a strong economy. I want to represent my community and be a voice for now and future generations.

candidates.name: Peter Koizumi
candidates.why_elect: I was born in the Waikato and have lived in Hamilton and the Waikato Region most of my life. Throughout my working careers I have engaged with the community and worked in roles directly helping people with special needs and requirements. I understand the time requirements of this role.
candidates.why_stand: I believe the challenges of climate change is not only in seeking the solutions but also understanding what causes climate change in our community. It is very clear it is the activities we undertake and therefore I want to work with the community to achieve a reduction in these effects.

candidates.name: Russ Rimmington
candidates.why_elect: I have given a lifetime of service to community service. Founded Fieldays with 7 others. As Mayor of Hamilton led dynamic growth with major new facilities. Transport centre, rugby stadium,Te Arohou women's new beginnings, 200 kms cycleways, 30,000 trees, walkway around Hamilton Lake, Innovation Park. Proven track record.
candidates.why_stand: We live in the golden triangle of NZ. Unfortunately there are still deep divisions between rich and poor. Poor transport to access Wintec and the Waikato University hinders access from rural towns. Public transport to Te Kuiti and the south is very poor. Those small towns are dying.

candidates.name: Barry Quayle
candidates.why_elect: I am able to interrogate,critically evaluate and then offer solutions which are sensible and achieve outcomes. Since joining council in 2017 I have influenced change and demonstrated a commitment to do that in a way that is positive for the community and region. I brought business intelligence to council.
candidates.why_stand: Waikato faces substantial challenges, so it is important we have effective Councillors. I offer broad experience, strong commitment, and believe in being a team player rather than pushing solo issues. Water quality and water use are big issues and we need strong and capable governance and stewardship.

candidates.name: William Durning
candidates.why_elect: I've lived in Hamilton with my family since we moved here over twenty years ago. I care equally about the environment, community and the economy. I'm open-minded to all points of view and I'm energetic and accessible. I'm prepared to engage with the community in ways that suit you.
candidates.why_stand: Significant challenges lie ahead of us from climate change and public transportation to improving water quality and growing a sustainable regional economy, these issues and the decisions made will impact others for generations to come. I have a strong commercial background, significance governance experience and a willingness to serve.

candidates.name: Andrew MacPherson
candidates.why_elect: My career as a rural veterinarian along with subsequent CEO and Board directorship roles provides me with a range of perspectives on a variety of subjects. My veterinary work enhanced my empathy and listening skills enabling me to engage with most people, I want to see prosperity for all.
candidates.why_stand: My skills and experience will add value to the WRC, this region has been good to me. I want to give back by using my governance skills to build a more vibrant community for everyone's benefit. We are significant part of the NZ economy which I want to build.

candidates.name: Stuart Kneebone
candidates.why_elect: I'm friendly and approachable, with a strong sense of community responsibility. I'm pragmatic, with a considered and evidence based approach towards decision making, focused on doing the right thing for the region and its communities.
candidates.why_stand: I'm passionate about our region, and the role of the regional council to ensure it remains a great place to live, work and play. I want to do my bit to ensure the decisions we make as a community are meeting the best interests of current and future generations.

candidates.name: Dan Armstrong
candidates.why_elect: Having spent nearly all my life in the King Country and Waipā, I understand the challenges that face us. Having worked in the region, supported community grounds and gained some governance experience I'm eager to bring experienced, community/critical minded abilities to the council table.
candidates.why_stand: I want locals to have someone at the council table that cares about the environment and climate change as much as they do—that's why I'm standing.

candidates.name: Jane Nees
candidates.why_elect: I am hardworking and conscientious, value honesty and integrity, and am people focused. I have a very strong management and governance background, understand local government, and I have a proven twelve year track record as a very experienced and effective Councillor. Check out my website www.janenees.co.nz to learn more.
candidates.why_stand: I've a real passion for the Bay of Plenty. I understand the challenges it faces and want to help make wise decisions for its future. I'm seeking re-election because I believe I can make a difference and want to work with our community to make "A Better Bay of Plenty."

candidates.name: Matthew Farrell
candidates.why_elect: I'm involved in the community as much as possible. I'm active here and now and for the next generation, not just this election. Vote for my common-sense, and I'll gain experience, turning my listening into doing. I will balance fair costs with prudent spending and wise project investment decisions.
candidates.why_stand: I believe elected representatives should publicise what they're doing through their time in office, and be transparent in their dealings without being invisible locally. I think a regional councillor should hear what locals want, then listen and act by advocating at regional council level, for the community.

candidates.name: Katie Priscilla Paul
candidates.why_elect: I law and arts degrees. I've worked as a NZ diplomat, for the government, with regional councils and for multimillion Boards and trusts. I'm a member of the NZ Institute of Directors. I'm comfortable on the marae, on a farm or in a boardroom. I'm a working mum.
candidates.why_stand: I live and work in Rotorua (some of our councillors don't). My regional rates are huge, but I don't see value. I want more funds for Rotorua communities. It's time for a fresh face with ideas that care for the elderly and invest in the youth.

candidates.name: Lyall Thurston
candidates.why_elect: Totally committed to Rotorua. Offering a strong, experienced, inclusive advocate to lead and espouse the issues and needs of Rotorua.
candidates.why_stand: Standing to present a strong, experienced voice for the Rotorua district.

candidates.name: Charles Lambert
candidates.why_elect: I have served a term as a Wairoa District Councillor (WDC). In this position I gained valuable experience with new fresh water regulations, with infrastructure and asset management, producing long term and annual plans. And the importance of genuine consultation. I can do this and I can do it well.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that we have the responsibility of handing over our lands and waterways to the next generation in the best condition possible. The biggest danger to our environment is us. That's why I'm here, I think we can make some positive changes.

candidates.name: Fenton Wilson
candidates.why_elect: I live and farm in Wairoa and have a wealth of governance experience from leadership positions over the last 10 years plus. It's a full time role and I have attended in excess of 90% of all meetings over my years as a councillor. I am prepared to work hard.
candidates.why_stand: Wairoa needs an experienced councillor to continue progress in transport, sensible land use, tourism opportunities and new developments such as a Wairoa regional park leverage funded with regional seeding cash. Progress takes time when you are working with multi agencies and I have the connections to accelerate success.

candidates.name: Hinewai Ormsby
candidates.why_elect: I believe our environment needs strong actions and not words. That's why I've grown, 3,000 native trees that have been planted along the Ahuriri Estuary. I'm a member of Forest and Bird, and co-wrote the Tūtaekurī River Management Plan to restore the ecological and environmental health of the Tūtaekurī River.
candidates.why_stand: I'm standing because I believes the HBRC has the duty to protect our environment. I'm concerned that water quality continues to degrade and our water is unswimmable. As a secondary school science teacher I believe I'll bring an evidence based approach to council. I want our region to thrive.

candidates.name: John Smith
candidates.why_elect: 41 of my 76 years in HB—Hastings in the 60s and Napier and environs since 1985. Rural and urban both residence and occupations Versatile and now with time and focus. First branch manager position at 23. Plenty of life left yet. Extensive wide ranging personal library.
candidates.why_stand: NZ deserves better than misinformation on climate and our future. As the nonsense has now filtered down to regional level, time to wind back at this level and take it to central government. Policies at all levels based on the "religion" of global warming is totalitarianism in the offing.

candidates.name: Martin Williams
candidates.why_elect: I have a decade of experience serving in governance roles for a number of community, charitable and educational organisations within Hawke's Bay. I am often told my contribution is highly valued for my clarity of thought, effective leadership and outcomes achieved. Basically getting on with it and 'the job done.'
candidates.why_stand: I want to make a meaningful contribution to Hawke's Bay, with the skills acquired through 25 years of practice in local government and environmental law. My practice is going strong. I literally don't need this job. I want this job. It's about the old fashioned ethic of service.

candidates.name: Paul Bailey
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Hawke's Bay all my life and have been based in Napier for the last 18 years. I have 4 children, two of whom are school age. I've been a Bank Manager and business owner and after one term am now an experienced and proven councillor.
candidates.why_stand: I see Hawke's Bay as being the world leader in making use of our natural environmental resources in a sustainable manner to bring prosperity to all.

candidates.name: Neil Kirton
candidates.why_elect: I engage my extensive experience in central and local government over 25 years to look after ratepayers. As chair of the audit and risk committee i have worked closely with the council's finance team and colleagues to ensure financial decisions are prudent, always protecting ratepayers interests.
candidates.why_stand: This council has produced an extraordinary turnaround in financial and environmental fortunes. I want to ensure the $140m increase in asset value and our far reaching environmental vision is protected. My job is to ensure investments are safe from think big schemes that cost ratepayers $20m last time round.

candidates.name: Nichola Nicholson
candidates.why_elect: I will serve Napier by listening to the community, understanding the science and working for sustainable solutions to environmental issues. I will work to make positive decisions on important issues including water, biodiversity, Ahuriri Estuary and climate change.
candidates.why_stand: I believe our regional council needs renewed energy and diversity. I can provide these by bringing a fresh perspective, a younger voice and experience to the table. I have a degree in environmental management. By working together, we can create a thriving region supported by a healthy environment, for everyone.

candidates.name: Guy Wellwood
candidates.why_elect: I am a clear and independent thinker that can be convinced of other arguments if they are good enough. I have lived and worked in Hawkes Bay for most of my life in good times and bad. I have always been prepared to listen and learn.
candidates.why_stand: After a career as a lawyer and a government and business adviser I would like the opportunity to be a politician which I define as one who works and debates with other councillors to reach consensus on priorities in the Region for the benefit of the environment and the economy.

candidates.name: Will Foley
candidates.why_elect: I have strong advocacy experience for Central Hawke's Bay. I have led Hawke's Bay Federated Farmers for five years. Combined with industry governance and leadership training including Kellogg Rural Leaders I have strong credentials to provide the necessary skills for around the regional council table.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about Central Hawke's Bay and its potential to thrive. I am keen to follow on from Councillor Hewitt to represent the people of Central Hawke's Bay and motivated to succeed with positive outcomes for our region.

candidates.name: Tony Kuklinski
candidates.why_elect: I currently serve as a volunteer rural fire fighter and I believe I could serve my community better as a regional councillor. I am genuinely passionate about farming and improving the environment. I have a particular interest in soil and the building up of organic matter in the soil.
candidates.why_stand: I see a need for a strong, practical voice at the regional council. I have a background in farming, growing and looking after and improving natural resources which will mean I can make informed decisions that help our community—both town and country.

candidates.name: Tim Gilbertson
candidates.why_elect: Because instead of bitching and whinging about how useless politicians are, like most of us do, I am prepared to try and do something about it.
candidates.why_stand: My philosophy is that an honest individual serving the long term interest of the entire region is a better option that a group funded and influenced by wealthy localised sector interests, especially where water security is concerned. I see my role as that of an honest individual.

candidates.name: Peter Guerin
candidates.why_elect: I grew up here then returned in 2015. I understand local government and its importance to communities. I have the time, energy, knowledge and commitment to make a difference. I will focus on the important matters that make a real difference to the environment and prosperity of our region.
candidates.why_stand: The regional council must do more to improve regional prosperity—by operating better, faster, cheaper, and making things easier for residents. With my 20 years experience as a local authority CEO, I can make a significant contribution to the debate and make a difference to regional policy.

candidates.name: Mary O'Neill
candidates.why_elect: I live in Hawke's Bay 14 years and I have a wealth of experience in the native plants research in Hastings and Havelock North. I completed 2 assignments in my majors on gastric outbreak 2016 in Havelock North prior I graduated with Bachelor of Applied Science Environment.
candidates.why_stand: I stand for Hastings constituency that encompasses Hastings, Havelock North and Clive. People choose to live here and call this place home. We have a great climate and potential to build environmental knowledge that will drive sustainable innovation—which would make us excellent. I will open that door!

candidates.name: Rick Barker
candidates.why_elect: Two council terms ensures I have a good grasp of the issues and processes. Great progress has been made in that time on all fronts and I wish to be part of the continuing improvement. Central government experience, with six years at the cabinet table provides good governance experience.
candidates.why_stand: The regional council is the environmental leader for our region, I wish to see it be an exceptional leader at improving water quality, that people swim in, fish thrive, help with water storage and conservation, lead on mitigating climate change while encouraging economic development.

candidates.name: Tom Belford
candidates.why_elect: I am super-diligent, with a reputation for digging into complex issues and advocating effectively. As editor of BayBuzz magazine, I listen—I am constantly exposed to the wide range of issues facing the community and the concerns people have.
candidates.why_stand: I believe the economic and social well-being of our region must be built on the foundation of a healthy, sustainable environment. Our present council majority shares that vision and I am seeking re-election to stay on that course.

candidates.name: Craig Foss
