candidates.why_elect: I walk the environmental and changing climate talk; starting at home, fencing streams; planting countless native trees; removing pests, creating a QEII conservation block and installing solar energy. My Backing The Bay for 12 years as a MP balanced with 14 years of banking demonstrates my governance and business experience.
candidates.why_stand: We need the Right Balance. Our families, communities and businesses views, values and expectations for transparency and accountability need to be around the council table. Havelock North, Hastings and Flaxmere residents will now have a clear choice.

candidates.name: Chris Wilkes
candidates.why_elect: I embrace the truth no matter how inconvenient it may be and speak with honesty and integrity. I am committed to bringing about the positive changes we need to ensure or continued prosperity as a region.
candidates.why_stand: I am determined to bring a voice for the environment to the council table. I am passionate about the preservation and enhancement of the natural environment and believe we haven't got it right yet, so I am hoping to contribute in some way to bringing the balance.

candidates.name: Charlotte Littlewood
candidates.why_elect: Director of Port Taranaki, on the Council of WITT and a chartered member of the Institute of Directors. I run my own business, and have a background in policy and regulation, having advised to the NZ and UK Governments. I've a degree in economics and a Masters in Finance.
candidates.why_stand: We live in a truly special region. It must be one the generations of tomorrow can enjoy, as much as we can today. If re-elected, I'll continue to advocate for our rivers being clean for swimming and our natural habitat thriving.

candidates.name: Elvisa Van Der Leden
candidates.why_elect: Contracting for government and non-government organizations has taught me the value of consultation, collaboration and communication. A background in marine science and media studies has led to over 5 years volunteering and working professionally in environmental science education and advocacy—all relevant to the works of regional council.
candidates.why_stand: Taranaki is a uniquely beautiful region—from the mountain to the sea—but there is still a lot of work to be done. In this rapidly changing world, I want to represent the diverse voices of Taranaki and support evidence-based decision making.

candidates.name: Bob Waugh
candidates.why_elect: I have extensive governance and management experience through involvement in community groups in Taranaki including New Plymouth Yacht Club, ESOL, Rotary, Trustee of Central School and NPGHS. I believe my strengths are seeing the bigger picture and innovation which I developed through my business servicing the oil and gas industry.
candidates.why_stand: In my life Taranaki has become the best place to live in NZ. I want our community to have the opportunities I had to be successful. I believe we need productive economic growth, recognising climate change, to protect our environment, enable infrastructure to maintain and grow our prosperity and lifestyle.

candidates.name: Rusty Kane
candidates.why_elect: I have been involved with local and national politics since 1997 first supporting Doug Wilson's protest walk from New Plymouth to Wellington, collected 56,000 signatures for a petition calling for the then Governor-General to impose a snap election. I then formed The People's Choice officially registered on 14 May 1999.
candidates.why_stand: After completing my OE, I looked around for the best place to live, work, and raise a family. New Plymouth ticked all the boxes. Having plentiful job opportunities, affordable housing, superb recreational facilities, civic pride, and a real sense of "can do" attitude.

candidates.name: Matthew Mcdonald
candidates.why_elect: As a second term councillor I will bring knowledge and the ability to work towards practical solutions and understand how to frame policy that is workable.
candidates.why_stand: I believe we are facing a time of over regulation and the direction of central government will bring challenges that will affect the regions and we need people who can look and solve issues in a practical way that is measurable and bring in policy that is balanced.

candidates.name: Neil Walker
candidates.why_elect: I have a wide experience of all areas of Taranaki life. I have developed a number of new businesses. I am a Scientist by profession and held national and international roles. I am locally involved in Health, Education, Hospitals, Rest Homes, Disability organisations, Church, Social services, etc.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about our Province. I want to balance environment and development to make it the best place to live. The aim is balance. I hold many roles in Taranaki and we need the whole community to be involved and cooperating together. Fostering the "Taranaki way" to do business.

candidates.name: Michael Joyce
candidates.why_elect: I have strong governance experience and currently have a number of key roles on Taranaki Regional Council committees.
candidates.why_stand: I want to work for the continuing improvement of environmental protection and enhancement of Taranaki while striving for a strong regional economy. I have the skills, passion and experience to make a real difference for the good of Taranaki and its people.

candidates.name: Alan Murray
candidates.why_elect: Accountancy and water treatment experience coupled with my agricultural/horticultural experience puts me in a position where I may be able to help educate those close to the coalface on the best environmental path forward.
candidates.why_stand: I spent 15 years as an agricultural consultant, promoting soil and animal health. I believe we have a lot to do to reach my ideal environmental aims. Education is the key, but we must start with the Council itself.

candidates.name: Moana Ellis
candidates.why_elect: My business degree, background in journalism, and work in Treaty settlement to unlock social and economic potential have equipped me with the analytical and critical thinking skills and strategic focus needed to solve problems without compromising ethics: in short, I'm detail-oriented with a big-picture focus.
candidates.why_stand: A strong local economy, profitable farming and booming business are critical for rural communities. How do we manage the challenges we face, and keep our community together? I'm standing because I believe in community and the need to face the work ahead together.

candidates.name: Weston Kirton
candidates.why_elect: Our family have lived in the district for nearly 100 years. I have farmed for over thirty years Annette and I are involved in community groups. I have over 15 years experience in local government. I believe I can add value and provide a strong voice on council.
candidates.why_stand: It is my view the Ruapehu District deserves an experienced candidate to represent the region. I have three years experience on Horizons and six years as a progressive. Mayor of the Ruapehu Council.

candidates.name: Richard Steele
candidates.why_elect: I have a record of strong local advocacy, see a need to one hand represent locals with a strong voice, while showing locals that saving the world will involve input from all of us.
candidates.why_stand: I love the place, but see that it needs to be looked after better.

candidates.name: Nicola Patrick
candidates.why_elect: I have diverse and relevant experience working at senior levels in the public, private, charitable and iwi sectors in Australia and NZ, as a volunteer, and I've served three years as a councillor. Educated in Whanganui, I have a science degree from Massey University and am mum to two boys.
candidates.why_stand: I stood for Horizons Regional Council because I love Whanganui and NZ and want to see them thrive. I believe in environmental, economic and social values underpinning good decision-making and want to make a difference as a regional councillor.

candidates.name: Leslie Pillow
candidates.why_elect: As a journalist I know how to ask the right questions, investigate any rorts and bring transparency to an organisation.
candidates.why_stand: For my grandchildren, to ensure they continue to enjoy a safe, natural environment in which to thrive.

candidates.name: Teresa Schulz
candidates.why_elect: As a local I feel a real connection to the Manawatu. I have integrity and a passion to make a real positive difference to planning and management in our region. My science, agriculture and economics backgrounds are extensive.
candidates.why_stand: I have lived in the Manawatu all my life. I want future generations to enjoy the kind of NZ I grew up in. I have skills which will be useful in helping to solve many of the environmental problems we currently experience and assist others to transition.

candidates.name: John Turkington
candidates.why_elect: I have a balance of commercial development experience and environmental work experience.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about our Region. I have been a positive contributor and have 40 years experience in Land Management.

candidates.name: Gordon McKellar
candidates.why_elect: I'm proud of my community involvement to clean up our local streams, and progress with our waterways involving the community working together. If re-elected as your Horizons councillor I'll bring proven and positive leadership experience to the big issues ensuring a bright future for you and generations to come.
candidates.why_stand: I am proud and passionate to live in this great region and would like to continue positively working for you in making our region the best region to live, work and play in. I will continue to build trust and good working relationships for environmental, community and economic enhancement.

candidates.name: Rachel Keedwell
candidates.why_elect: In my two terms on Horizons, I have been a committed and passionate advocate for people and the environment. I've positively influenced council debates and actions and I have consistently pushed for sustainability in all council decision-making.
candidates.why_stand: The regional council is well represented by business and farming interests but does not have a strong environmental voice, despite its crucial role of environmental stewardship. I will use my skills as an ecologist to advocate for sound environmental management to ensure there is a future for all our children.

candidates.name: Jono Naylor
candidates.why_elect: I believe that my 17 years experience in local and central government alongside my community involvement ensures that I well equipped to continue to serve our community in this role.
candidates.why_stand: I am committed to this region and have devoted a good part of my life to improving it where I can. I want to ensure that we are doing the best for our environment and our people now and into the future.

candidates.name: Chris Teo-Sherrell
candidates.why_elect: Hard-working, knowledgeable and of highest integrity—that's how others describe me. I also have 9 years experience on city council, 6 years at central government, a PhD, plus decades of commitment to environmental protection and seeking fairness. I stand up for what I believe and I walk my talk.
candidates.why_stand: We are at a crossroads. Decisions need to be made now to enable this region to thrive environmentally, socially and economically in the face of climate change and other challenges. With my experience, contacts and knowledge I can help us make the decisions that will make the necessary changes easier.

candidates.name: Darryl Cleland
candidates.why_stand: I'm a born and bred manawatu lad, attended Pnth boys high. Keen outdoor sportsman. Trish and myself have brought up our three children here. Love the place, now want to give something back. To make sure manawatu will still be great for my future generations.

candidates.name: Jack Dowds
candidates.why_elect: I have lived here for a long time and my experience in governance, local government management as CEO of a District Council and general management equip me to be an effective representative. I understand both the technical and financial areas of local government.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about this region and I believe that I can contribute to its well-being and development.

candidates.name: Fiona Gordon
candidates.why_elect: As a local business woman, mum of two, Trustee to the Palmerston North City Environmental Trust and an Ambassador to the Jane Goodall Institute NZ, I understand what matters in our community. I'm backed by my tertiary qualifications and 24+ years' experience in resource management, including within local government.
candidates.why_stand: I live here because I love it—the lifestyle, landscape and environment. But our environment is not being adequately safeguarded. I'm stepping up, to offer my background and skills in resource management to help make better, long term decisions for a healthy environment and resilient communities.

candidates.name: Sam Ferguson
candidates.why_elect: I am approachable and good at listening. During the current campaign I have been running street corner meetings for the purpose of hearing from local people. I will continue to be approachable when elected and hear from our local people. I live in Levin and will represent the town voice.
candidates.why_stand: I am a strong advocate for our environment, especially our water. I want to ensure we leave our environment in a better condition than we received it. The regional council has responsibility for environmental protection and I will be a strong voice at the table for our town and environment.

candidates.name: Michael Kay
candidates.why_elect: My experience and knowledge of Regenerative Agriculture, to regenerate the soil is the first step to a permanent culture or permaculture. These two agricultural sciences are a transition from agrarian traditional farming that NZ agriculture was. Regenerative agriculture is the repair system for resilient farming and strong communities.
candidates.why_stand: Climate change and environmental impact of farming is the challenge that we must get right. Climate fear and environmental impact can be dealt with if we draw from all the tools. My prime concern is a monoculture of temporary solutions has captured our ability to respond as kiwis.

candidates.name: Phil Taueki
candidates.why_elect: My commitment to the restoration of Lake Horowhenua and the Hokio stream is well known and I have been fighting to clean up our waterways since returning from overseas in 2004. My whānau have lived in the Horowhenua for several hundred years. I relate well with people.
candidates.why_stand: A large group of supporters have asked me to stand. My duty is in my DNA and as tangata whenua it is my responsibility to protect and safeguard our environment, particularly our water-ways.

candidates.name: Karen Adams
candidates.why_elect: I am independent, any opinions are my own, they are wide and varied as are my professional, family and social circles. This variety means I have and continue to network with many varied groups, in NZ and internationally giving a wider world view to many issues and importantly solutions.
candidates.why_stand: I am tired of the regional council's response to the hard environmental issues that affect our region and its people and believe there is no political will to make any real changes with the majority of current councillors who are connected or have business interests in either development or farming.

candidates.name: Lindsay Burnell
candidates.why_elect: I've lived in the community my whole life and have been involved in many organisations, including education, farming, electricity (helped set up the Electra Trust) sporting, District Council, Health Board, Coast Access Radio. A.P.and I association.
candidates.why_stand: I am running for re-election because of the knowledge and experience that I have gained over the years I have been on Council I have dealt with the issues of growth in the Horowhenua and have an excellent understanding of the community.

candidates.name: Emma Clarke
candidates.why_elect: I have lived, in this region for over 40 years. During this time I have been involved in a variety of governance positions. I am a director of two companies. I represent the Horowhenua on the Vegetables NZ crop advisory group, and the NZGAP committee, a world wide accreditation program.
candidates.why_stand: In an era of ever increasing change I want to be part of the solutions, to help preserve all the reasons why this region has been so special to me growing up and raising a family in.

candidates.name: Andrew Day
candidates.why_elect: I'm a third generation sheep, beef and dairy support farmer with an Ag-science degree and have a track record of ensuring our natural resources are used in a fair and equitable manner that provides for future generations. It's about creating a level playing field for all.
candidates.why_stand: I'm standing for Horizons because I believe Tararua can have both a thriving prosperous economy and a natural environment to be proud of, so it remains a great place to work and play for future generations.

candidates.name: Lorraine Stephenson
candidates.why_elect: I have 35 years local, regional and national governance experience. Resource Management background, Hearing Commissioner for 25 years. Extensive community/volunteer work in Tararua. I am politically savvy, self driven, analytical,strategic, culturally aware and not afraid of hard work. I am Māori and a woman who is well qualified for the role.
candidates.why_stand: Born and bred in Tararua, lived and worked on the land all my life. I am a caretaker/kaitiaki of the land. I am passionate about Tararua and my life's work has paved a clear pathway to a role with Horizons Regional Council. It is my turn,my time to represent Tararua.

candidates.name: Neil Mackay
candidates.why_elect: Through my roles as Chair of Electra, Chief Executive of Industry NZ (Government economic development agency) and Chair of the Kapiti Aquatic Centre Trust I have developed good governance, partnership and leadership skills and experience. This experience equips me well to represent Kapiti effectively on the Regional Council.
candidates.why_stand: I love the Kapiti Coast. I have lived here with my family for the last 30 years. Its critical for Kapiti's well-being that it strengthen its economic base and nurture its natural and built environment. I want to advocate on behalf of the Kapiti constituency to make this happen.

candidates.name: Jenny Brash
candidates.why_elect: I love local government and have decades of knowledge and experience—as a local Porirua City Councillor, Mayor of Porirua City for 12 years and on the Greater Wellington Regional Council since 2010. I have lived in Porirua City for almost 40 years and worked in Wellington City.
candidates.why_stand: I love our Wellington Region with its beautiful and diverse environments, distinctive and different communities and mix of urban and rural. This is a crucial time for the environment with regional councils having to implement National Environmental Standards, National Policy statements for Freshwater and Urban Development and an RMA review.

candidates.name: Phillip Marshall
candidates.why_elect: I have a wealth of experience working to help NZers and their families in our community. I care about all of the people in our community and want to see that their lives are improved. If I can do that in any little way then I have succeeded.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that we need a New Deal for public transport. We deserve a cheap, reliable, frequent service. When I saw what was happening to the buses and trains I knew I had to stand as I want to do all I can to help make it world-class.

candidates.name: Vaughn Liley
candidates.why_elect: I've lived here my whole life. I'm committed to protecting the quality of our natural and built environments. I volunteer for Friends of Tawa Bush Reserves, who plant trees in and maintain trails in our reserves. I pay attention to the details. I can exercise prudent oversight of our council.
candidates.why_stand: I'm running for council because I see the declining quality of our railway stations, our poor public transport connections and frequencies, the litter the council's contractors leave in our reserves. I'm not prepared to idly stand by while these problems persist, escaping the attention of our councillors.

candidates.name: Chris Kirk-Burnnand
candidates.why_elect: I have proven success in both business management and in governance of voluntary organisations and believe I can bring those skills to the Council.
candidates.why_stand: I am running for election because I feel the poor transport decisions and change implementation reflect a non professional governance by existing Council. I have always taken a sound interest in our community and believe that I can help to bring about better decisions and sound cost control.

candidates.name: Barbara Donaldson
candidates.why_elect: I'm a long term resident of Porirua with experience as a Chief Executive, hospital manager and international quality consultant. I have worked hard as a Regional Councillor for the past twelve years. I have the knowledge, skills and commitment to make the council more responsive and to protect our future.
candidates.why_stand: I want our extraordinary region to flourish and be sustainable, resilient and connected. It has huge challenges in earthquake strengthening its infrastructure, responding to the threats of climate change and improving the health of its waterways. Economic development needs to be coordinated so all our citizens can thrive.

candidates.name: Roger Watkin
candidates.why_elect: I have a successful business background and have a strong community involvement through several voluntary organisations. I am a good communicator and will operate a two way system between Greater Wellington and our local council and community board (Tawa) and other community representative groups. I have strong community advocacy skills.
candidates.why_stand: I have had huge support to stand from communities from Tawa to Plimmerton. I have experience and a fresh perspective to offer. All organisations need a refresh and Greater Wellington is due for this. I am dedicated to ensuring our part of the region as a staunch advocate at GW.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Uta/Upper Hutt
candidates.name: Mark Crofskey
candidates.why_elect: I have had twenty years of legal and business experience and am a passionate advocate for Upper Hutt. Upper Hutt deserves the very best representation and a professional hard-working person to put its case forward at the Greater Wellington Regional Council.
candidates.why_stand: I grew up in Upper Hutt and was educated at Saint Pat's Silverstream. I want my kids to live in a Region that is sustainable and easy to get around. I am standing to advocate for Upper Hutt's and the wider Wellington Region's fair share of the national transport budget.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Uta/Upper Hutt
candidates.name: Bill Hammond
candidates.why_stand: Sometimes you have to stand up for what you believe. I believe I can make a difference and make Upper hutt a better place with a river we can be proud of, better value for money for our rates and be a common sense voice on the gwrc.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Uta/Upper Hutt
candidates.name: Ros Connelly
candidates.why_elect: I am passionate, hard-working and strategic. I love representing Upper Hutt, meeting members of our community and solving problems. I am an experienced local councillor and understand the issues facing the Wellington region's land, air, water and ecosystem management. As a trained scientist I am able to interpret technical information.
candidates.why_stand: I care about the Wellington Region (particularly Upper Hutt) and want to protect and enhance our natural assets while promoting regional growth. Plus, after the 'bustastrophe' I decided that new energy was needed on Council—a new injection of Councillors who aren't hamstrung by previous decisions they have made.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Uta/Upper Hutt
candidates.name: Steve Pattinson
candidates.why_elect: I've lived in Upper Hutt for 25 years and been a community advocate for the last 7 years. I've made multiple submissions to regional and local councils on public transport, housing and urban development, forestry management and regional parks. I listen to local knowledge and will be the people's voice.
candidates.why_stand: I think Wellington region has great potential. I want to create a culture of genuine public consultation and engagement, with greater transparency, focussing on people's wellbeing in all areas of council's decision making. We need a holistic approach to find integrated solutions that resolve the regions complex issues more efficiently.

CON_0903.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Uta/Upper Hutt

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Tai/Lower Hutt
candidates.name: Prue Lamason

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Tai/Lower Hutt
candidates.name: David Ogden
candidates.why_elect: I have proven by results as a former mayor and councillor that teamwork and a great vision that achievements can be made that are the best in NZ.
candidates.why_stand: I still wish to serve the people of our region.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Tai/Lower Hutt
candidates.name: Josh van Lier
candidates.why_elect: I've worked as a scientist for nearly a decade trying to better understand our forests, rivers, estuaries and coasts. My experience in climate and environmental science means I can ask the questions many councillors currently wouldn't know to, and can lead from the front on these critical issues.
candidates.why_stand: My generation will face the consequences of our climate and biodiversity crises. It is critical we have a voice around the table. I want to be that voice. I want to use the GWRCs mandate for transport and the environment to ensure Lower Hutt has a prosperous and sustainable future.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Tai/Lower Hutt
candidates.name: Leonie Dobbs
candidates.why_elect: I have been involved in a number communities—recently helping get a basketball court in Stokes Valley, set up Dress for Success Wellington, driving many changes for Jackson Street business and building owners in Petone. Keeping history of Petone as an asset for the Region.
candidates.why_stand: I am running in this election to sort out the transport system from the Hutt Valley. As a use of the service, it has been extremely frustrating for customers. This has affect the learning and productivity in the region for businesses and in our education sector.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Tai/Lower Hutt
candidates.name: Peter Glensor
candidates.why_elect: A very proud local, I'm offering again my experience and energy, my drive and skills for a strong region. I'll keep listening and talking to you. I'll spell out the options, make decisions and drive action to improve our communities and safeguard future generations.
candidates.why_stand: I did this work already for 9 years and demonstrated success in transport, flood protection, community engagement. I transformed the trains and want to help with the buses. Climate change is happening already and needs an urgent, determined response—both impact reduction and publicly supported adaptation.

candidates.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Tai/Lower Hutt
candidates.name: Ken Laban

CON_0904.electorate: Te Awa Kairangi ki Tai/Lower Hutt

candidates.name: Helene Ritchie
candidates.why_elect: I have a wealth of experience, I practice transparent democratic governance, and have served on the past twice on regional councils. I was the first female Labour Leader on Wellington City Council, and now after a three year "sabbatical" writing, I stand as an Independent, city wide and the region.
candidates.why_stand: As the first female mayor and longest serving city councillor, I am offering extensive (over 21 diverse boards and councils) experience in leadership and governance. That experience has extended to transport Boards over many years. and a focus on the Environment. I want to "fix the buses!" (with others!).

candidates.name: Anand Kochunny
candidates.why_elect: Because I stand for these five values of a representative democracy: consultation; collaboration; transparency; accountability; responsibility. Because my platform is to change the organisational culture at our council to one where these five values are embedded into the DNA of the organisation. Because I'll be measured by what I do.
candidates.why_stand: I'm running for election to transform the organisational culture at our council. Buses aren't the problem; they are merely symptoms of a poor organisational culture which leads to flawed decision-making, resulting in perverse outcomes for Wellingtonians. With 13 councillors true to my five values, we can change the organisational culture.

candidates.name: Roger Blakeley
candidates.why_elect: I am very committed to serving people and communities. I have had previous experience as NZ's Secretary for the Environment and Secretary for Local Government, Chief Executive of Porirua City Council and international experience as Chair of the Paris-based OECD Environment Committee. I understand how governments work at all levels.
candidates.why_stand: I think that local government is at the front line of service to communities, and regional councils have responsibilities that cover the most interesting and challenging issues, such as public transport, climate change, environmental quality, freshwater quality, clean safe bulk drinking water, protecting native species, and coping with disasters.

candidates.name: Daran Ponter
candidates.why_elect: I am an experienced Councillor with a background in public policy. I have a reputation for listening and acting, facing down issues. and standing up for Wellingtonians.
candidates.why_stand: I believe in Wellington! A want a City that is a liveable and connected place for all Wellingtonians.

candidates.affiliation: Sam the Man With the Plan
candidates.name: Sam Somers
candidates.why_elect: A councillor's job doesn't finish at 5pm at night, a good councillor gets out and attends all the local residents association meetings, attend weekend events, and make sure they keep talking with the community.
candidates.why_stand: I would like to see the right changes coming forward from people of my generation at age 28, not have decisions made on by people who have only worked 9-5 Monday to Friday.

candidates.name: Lesleigh Salinger
candidates.why_elect: I established and chaired Karori Residents Association for the last six years in Wellington's largest suburb and worked with the city and regional councils, liaising and lobbying, effecting change. I have extensive leadership and management experience. I am goal oriented with a reputation for getting things done—an excellent communicator.
candidates.why_stand: I'm a proud born and bred Wellingtonian who believes passionately in the importance of good town planning, well-maintained infrastructure and well-run networks in underpinning the quality of life for residents. I have the experience and knowledge accumulated over a full and rich life to give an overview of the region.

candidates.name: Tony Jansen
candidates.why_elect: I would make a good representative because I am not a career politician hamstrung by Party dogma, orders or interests. I am not a celebrity politician either. I am one of you. If you vote for me I will listen and act for you for the next three years.
candidates.why_stand: I am running because our elected officials have stopped listening to the people and are not making good decisions on their behalf. I love my city and region. I am in a position to repay the good fortune I have enjoyed in life. It is time for a change.

candidates.name: David Lee
candidates.why_elect: As a Wellington City Councillor and an urban planner (25+ years experience in central and local government) I know how to get things done. I lead WCC's work in climate change, technology, innovation and enterprise. Wellington—with our low carbon emissions—is crowned the greenest city in Australasia.
candidates.why_stand: Wellington is my chosen home. I love how liveable it is—and it can be even better! I'll bring fresh vision, new ideas, energy and more diversity to Greater Wellington City Council.

candidates.name: Troy Mihaka
candidates.why_elect: I have a background in Conservation/Environmentalism, Tourism and Culture/Arts. I have spent a number of years volunteering in Conservation and Environmentalism, working in the Arts for the not-for-profit sector or running businesses in Tourism. All working to help improve the lifestyle of our city.
candidates.why_stand: I believe Wellington needs to plan for resilience into the future. As our city expands, we need to consider our future by ensuring we support sustainable growth. This means building integrated transport options, while considering the effect of growth on our unique environment and native wildlife.

candidates.name: Victoria Rhodes-Carlin
candidates.why_elect: With strong experience in governance, project management, complemented with my environmental science degree, I'm equipped to be a dedicated advocate for Wellington. As a renter, a student and a public transport user, I reflect a large portion of our city and am willing to be a platform for others.
candidates.why_stand: Wellington is a diverse, vibrant and innovation region, but I believe we need leadership that actually reflects our young and diverse population. I am passionate about climate justice, accessibility, inclusiveness, and sustainability, to which our council lacks. We need transformational change to tackle increasing inequalities and environmental challenges.

candidates.name: Alexander Garside
candidates.why_elect: I feel I will bring a practical perspective to the council chamber. As a photographer and postie, I'm constantly involved in both this region's natural beauty and the physical layout of people's lives.
candidates.why_stand: I believe Wellington has a future as a thriving, livable global city. I'm running with an optimism for what the region could achieve with an ambitious long-term vision.

candidates.name: Yvonne Legarth
candidates.why_elect: I am passionate about people being able to have their say. I offer extensive experience with public processes, sound analytic skills and a solid record of supporting people in my community. I'm committed to protecting our stunning natural environment, valuing our harbour, rivers, wetlands and coastline.
candidates.why_stand: Good governance is important. I want to ensure good decisions are made, that people have access to public information and are told about things happening in their neighbourhoods that affect them. I want the council's policies and strategies to consider the needs of the diverse community we live in.

candidates.name: Glenda Hughes
candidates.why_elect: My involvement on Boards of sports organisations, charities such as KidsCan and Petrefuge, my service on the Parole Board, Chairing of the NZRB and the Integrity Unit and my 18yrs as a Police Officer has given me a package of skills that I would like to use for my city.
candidates.why_stand: I am a born and bred Wellingtonian, an inner city dweller. I have become very concerned with the current direction of my favourite city GWRC needs to be run as a major community business and I would like to contribute my experience to achieving this.

candidates.affiliation: Fixing the Buses and Public Transport
candidates.name: Bryce Pender
candidates.why_elect: Born and bred in the region I have seen it grow, expand and struggle, this is my time to be part of the solution.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing to bring forward a total vision for the regions transport, encouraging PT use, to fix the issues that have been plaguing the system since last year, to bring forward active and quick responses to issues that crop up.

candidates.name: Thomas Nash
candidates.why_elect: I have a track record of international success as an effective leader. I led the global campaign to ban cluster bombs and have 20 years of experience in senior leadership, financial management and governance. I understand Wellington as a renter and public transport user—two groups underrepresented on councils.
candidates.why_stand: The regional council needs culture change and new ideas. We've got a lot of work to do in a short time. Greater Wellington has committed to being carbon neutral by 2030—that's a big job. I've got the skills and experience to build agreement around the changes we need.

candidates.name: Jill Ford
candidates.why_elect: Making a positive difference has been a driving force all my life. For over 30 years I have taken action that made a difference, as a volunteer, my own business, in not for profit and government sectors. I will bring fresh ideas, experience and am not afraid to challenge the status quo.
candidates.why_stand: My aspiration is for a truly liveable region for everyone, and a low carbon future that values our natural environment. Where councils and government work together collaboratively to ensure we have a region that is easy to get around and fit for the future, so we have healthy, connected communities.

candidates.name: Tony De Lorenzo
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in operations and worked in governance. Being an ideas person and an initiator and get things started so that things don't just get talked about, they get done. My business acumen allows me to evaluate and reduce risk so that projects and initiatives are achieved successfully.
candidates.why_stand: I love living in Wellington and think it is the greatest place on earth to live. The culture of creativity and engagement in the in the arts and business is amazing and truly inspiring. I have developed so much in this environment that I want to give something back.

candidates.name: Phil Quin
candidates.why_elect: Coming home to Wellington in 2018 after too long away, I am a writer, trainer and strategic communications consultant with decades of experience advising governments, private sector clients and NGOs. Former Labour staffer in NZ and Australia and Porirua City Councillor (1989-93).
candidates.why_stand: After the bus debacle, the regional council needs new leaders and a fresh spirit of democratic accountability. We need to fix the buses and future proof the trains.

candidates.name: John Klaphake
candidates.why_elect: I will bring critical thinking to the equation and provoke fresh, innovative perspectives rather than the old, entrenched thinking that has been applied in the past and simply hasn't been doing us any favours.
candidates.why_stand: I want to provoke critical thinking and timely action about our finite resources and ensure the voice of all citizens is protected and advanced. I want to see a Council that is Transparent, that Communicates, Collaborates and actively Consults with it's community.

candidates.name: Adrienne Staples
candidates.why_elect: I bring strength, experience and commitment to the role. My proven track record of getting things done was made by gaining respect, having a strong voice whenever necessary and being open minded about change. I continue to follow these principles as they work well in today's world.
candidates.why_stand: I love the Wairarapa and want to see it flourish. We have diverse needs depending on whether you live in the country or one of our towns. As a farmer who has also lived in the city I am capable of representing all of those voices at a regional level.

candidates.name: Richard L Moore
candidates.why_elect: In 2017 I was nominated for Wellingtonian of the Year (Environment Category) for my life's work in turning the region's waste polystyrene into 100% recycled globally unique durable building products. My daughter said "You are the cleverest man I know." I stand because our youth must inherit a better world.
candidates.why_stand: I stand for measurable achievement towards the better more sustainable future. I stand as an alternative to career politicians because a perspective on real world solutions requires real world experience. I stand for urban, for rural, for young and old. I stand because there are no problems, only solutions.

candidates.name: Pat Wall
candidates.why_elect: Because I am open, honest and believe in a two way dialogue between representatives and the public. Furthermore, in my day job I work with many local councils on climate change and GHG related issues, and can bring much needed climate perspectives to council.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that Coasters are ready to talk about climate change, and they need Councillors who are not in denial about it. I think Coasters are seeing the impacts with their own eyes, and they want someone to carry their concerns to council.

candidates.name: Glenn Irving
candidates.why_elect: I have been in both management and governance roles, and have a proven record in getting things done. I have existing relationships with people from a wide variety of organisations, and an engineering background that will enable me to make well informed decisions for our region.
candidates.why_stand: I'm proud to call the Coast home, but know that we can do a better job of caring for this incredible land we have been entrusted with. I also want it to be a place my children are proud of, and care for alongside all of us who live here.

candidates.name: Laura Coll McLaughlin
candidates.why_elect: I'm a licensed cadastral surveyor and planning consultant. I hold a Bachelor of Surveying with First Class Honours and associate memberships of the NZ Planning Institute and Survey and Spatial NZ. I'm Chair of the HBWCT board, an adult education tutor and have governance training. I'm a sixth-generation West Coaster.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about local participation in local decision making. I want to help empower our community to determine its own future in a way that is proactive, sustainable and responsible. I love this place.

candidates.name: John Hill
candidates.why_elect: As a qualified industrial chemist I have developed a broad knowledge of relevant issues such as climate change, waste management, coastal erosion. As I have lived in many towns around the UK, Australia and NZ I bring outside experience to our small community.
candidates.why_stand: I came to the coast to plan for a retirement in a stress free rural environment. After 13 years I have not retired but love living here with no close neighbours and lovely surroundings. However issues such as reliable health care must be addressed.

candidates.name: Andy Thompson
candidates.why_elect: I have experience in Farming, Mining, and Tourism as well as previous council experience. I work with DOC as an engagement advisor on the Paparoa Track Project and host a rural radio show "The Muster" I am a member of civil defense and an owner of Agfest West Coast.
candidates.why_stand: The West Coast Regional Council is the one entity that covers the entire Coast. We need to balance our communities environmental expectations alongside our need for economic development by using our extractive industries, farming, and tourism. These requirements may seem to be mutually exclusive but I refuse to believe this.

candidates.name: Paul Finlay
candidates.why_elect: Experience in the Bohol M7.2 Earthquake recovery for 1.3 million people, working for five years with the Dano Municipality and three years as Professor of Civil Engineering at HNU University.
candidates.why_stand: Because of the shock of climate Change. Because of the pending AF8 Seismic event The West Coast from Karamea to Jackson Bay is worthy of protection.

candidates.name: Stuart Challenger
candidates.why_elect: I am a Natural Resource Engineer, which gives me a good understanding of both the hard and soft process involved in development. I have a good understanding of the drivers of the West Coast residents through my work and sporting involvement over the years.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that the West Coast has a great future, however, there are a large number of people looking for short terms gains and not considering the long term. I am standing for consideration of what we want the West Coast to be in 20 years.

candidates.name: Logan John Skinner
candidates.why_elect: I will drive action and accountability at WCRC. I grew up on a farm and am now involved in tourism so understand some of the key industries in Westland first hand. I have worked for the Government Auditor Audit NZ in the past and seen good and bad governance.
candidates.why_stand: We need more action and accountability from WCRC. Too often problems are ignored until they become an expensive "emergency" fix—such as the Hokitika sea wall.

candidates.name: John Faulkner
candidates.why_elect: I have been engaged in community service for 30 years, Chair of School Board, and Employer's Group, X Victim Support Counselor Homicide trained, Rural and Branch banker, Commercial and Agribusiness University qualified and a Dairy Farmer fully understand environmental and cultural change required, believe collaboration provides equitable social acceptable progress.
candidates.why_stand: 12 years involved in the CWMS strongly believe we need to deliver on ground environmental actions in the most cost effective manner, collaboration and community buy in both urban and rural can speed the process up. Regulation is a blunt tool, the RMA, NPS etc show direction landowners engagement is crucial.

candidates.name: Garry Jackson
candidates.why_elect: I'm a proud passionate Cantabrian, and founding trustee of a progressive think tank for Canterbury's future. I have proven and successful leadership and governance experience as Hurunui Mayor, and can capably represent urban and rural interests. I bring balance, energy, strategic insight, and a common sense environmentally responsible approach.
candidates.why_stand: Ecan is returning to a fully elected model at a time when new challenges are looming, and the competence and capability of the new Ecan Council will be critical for Canterbury's future. I want to be part of that Council, giving North Canterbury strong and effective representation.

candidates.name: Claire McKay
candidates.why_elect: I have a detailed understanding of the complexity of the issues we face in managing our natural resources,including the challenge of finding economic and workable solutions to reduce environmental impacts. I'm committed to transparent and consultative engagement and strengthening collaborative relationships with stakeholders, in an environment of trust and respect.
candidates.why_stand: North Canterbury needs a strong advocate with a thorough knowledge and understanding of the key issues facing our district and region.

candidates.name: Greg Byrnes
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in local and regional government in the North Canterbury region for over twenty five years and am currently a GM for an environmental trust. I believe I have a good understanding of government and the issues impacting our constituency.
candidates.why_stand: I have worked in local and regional government in the North Canterbury region for over 25 years and currently as an environmental trust GM. During this time I seen a steady decline in the environmental values of the lands and rivers. This is not a legacy to leave future generations.

candidates.name: Bill Dowle
candidates.why_elect: I am approachable and have relationships with people from all sectors of the Canterbury society. As a Real Estate salesperson I see and deal with anyone and have a wide range of contacts to get the opinions and sentiments from. I am also negotiating with people all the time.
candidates.why_stand: I have lived in Kaikoura and Waimakariri Districts and now live in Hurunui. I have had dealings with ECan as a landowner, river committee member and contractor so have seen it from all angles and feel I can help improve the performance at various levels.

candidates.name: Grant Edge
candidates.why_elect: I have lived and worked in North Canterbury for the past 13 years and have considerable experience in land management (rural and urban) with knowledge in dealing with the regulatory processes. As Deputy Chair of the Waimakariri Zone committee I have participated in a community collaborative approach to decision making.
candidates.why_stand: Our region has some of the most diverse and beautiful landscapes in NZ. I am concerned at the level of environmental degradation of land and water resources across the region, and want to ensure that future policies (urban and rural) commit to achieving environmental improvement at a much faster pace.

candidates.name: Chrys Horn
candidates.why_elect: I've worked in both in science and in community both as a researcher and as a community developer and advocate. As such I'm a generalist who puts together information and ideas from a wide base and works well in a team to develop workable solutions to problems.
candidates.why_stand: I am deeply concerned at the condition of our Canterbury environment and the effect that has and will have on our collective wellbeing. In many cases we know what we need to do, but we need to work together to achieve it. It is time to get on with it!

candidates.name: Drucilla Denise Kingi-Patterson
candidates.why_elect: I look at the big picture. 35 years seminars, 30 years community groups film, drama, business. If Auckland were to get 2030 Commonwealth Games Biosecurity would be needed plus economic benefits to NZ if we plan and have a long term strategy to be ready for this and other major events.
candidates.why_stand: I have big concerns on Civil Defence of Canterbury. I was in Cathedral Square on 15 March 2019. Over 1500 people present many young. We are at a new point to rebuild Christchurch and outline areas and we must get it right. I have a vision for Canterbury.

candidates.name: Craig Pauling
candidates.why_elect: I am of both Māori and European descent, and understand the need to balance perspectives. I have over 20 years experience in environmental affairs, across professional and community roles. I am an action and solutions focused person and believe we need creativity and cooperation in making tough decisions.
candidates.why_stand: Being born and raised here, I care deeply about our home, but am concerned about the current state of our waterways and biodiversity, as well as the challenges of climate change. I want to make a positive contribution to these issues and bring a fresh perspective to the table.

candidates.name: Aaron Campbell
candidates.why_elect: I offer broad professional experience and with a degree in Consumer and Applied Science I will always put human health first. I am proud of my whakapapa As a community board member I've been a strong advocate for our awa. I spoke out against mandatory chlorination lobbyists and water bottling.
candidates.why_stand: Water is the primary issue facing Canterbury, and time's up.

candidates.name: Rod Cullinane
candidates.why_elect: I am an experienced professional who understands the issues and how they need to be addressed. For example how to tighten nitrogen leaching limits; how to limit expenditure to halt rates increases; how to minimise effects on residents of industrial activity such as quarrying.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing for re-election to ensure that work continues to reduce the impact of intensive farming on our waterways and eliminate threats to our drinking water. Our freshwater fisheries are in crisis. I am opposed to further rates increases and the only Councillor who voted against these.

candidates.name: Megan Hands
candidates.why_elect: My focus is on achieving sustainable outcomes for our region, not on political point scoring. My background in environmental consultancy and qualifications in resource management along with my experience with the CWMS to date places me well to hit the ground running.
candidates.why_stand: I'm running for election because I believe Canterbury is an incredible region to call home. I want to ensure that it continues to be the best place for young families like my own to live, work and explore.

candidates.name: Sarah Walters
candidates.why_elect: With a background that is both rural and urban, I will seek to build relationships to break down barriers and improve outcomes for everyone. I also offer a proven track record of previous local government experience. I am impartial, focused and committed.
candidates.why_stand: I was motivated to stand for Selwyn District Council in 2007 because I wanted to create a better world for our children. Even now, following a three year break after three terms as a councillor that motivation is still strong.

candidates.name: Allen Lim
candidates.why_elect: I understand the tensions of water management from many perspectives: as someone with children swimming in local rivers, a keen tramper, a vegetable grower, degree qualified engineer, businessman, and someone who has been in the water management space long enough to be asked to advice ministers.
candidates.why_stand: I have been concerned about the state of our waterways for a long time as shown by my 5+ years of work in the Selwyn Waihora Zone Committee and industry groups. I have the skills and determination to now move my work to the regional level.

candidates.name: Ian Mackenzie
candidates.why_elect: I have considerable experience in governance over a broad spectrum of commercial and community organisations. I have also worked in the water and environment areas at local, regional and national level and understand the science and public expectations. I can bring balance and sense to debate and decision making.
candidates.why_stand: My community asked me to stand as they trust my experience, skills and competence especially in the areas of water, the environment and transport. Our family have lived in the Canterbury region since the early 1840's and I hope my children and grandchildren will continue to do so.

candidates.name: John Sunckell
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in the community all my life and have a broad range of community involvement and leadership, particularly in farming, health and environmental management.
candidates.why_stand: Having done one term I am just getting to the point of understanding how to be genuinely effective as a Councillor and I am now in a position to face the challenges that are coming at us in the next few years.

candidates.name: Jared Ross
candidates.why_elect: I have a long association with the Waitaki Valley and sound experience operating environmentally responsible farming business. I am well connected in my community and have diverse industry involvement and exposure. I understand that the role is not about me, it is informed representation for our community.
candidates.why_stand: I feel compelled to take part in my generations' leadership of positive change. There is a concerning intensity of division between and within our communities. I have strong support from my local community. I have an appetite for contributing to balanced and fair decision making processes.

candidates.name: Peter J Scott
candidates.why_elect: My family has lived in South Canterbury since emigrating from Ireland in the 1860's. I have no political ties. I have made sure I have no affiliations to any lobby group or NGO's I will listen follow up and get back to you.
candidates.why_stand: I believe I have been part of a strong council in the move back to democracy. I want to ensure that the new council can have a good transition to a fully elected council. South Canterbury needs strong reliable leaders. I can represent South Canterbury well.

candidates.name: Herstall Ulrich
candidates.why_elect: With many years of governance experience, currently a member of the OTOP zone committee, I have learnt to listen and take on board differing points of view, consider the facts and consult as widely as necessary. I am the third generation to farm our land and third generation South Cantabrian.
candidates.why_stand: I am running, firstly in response to much encouragement from peers, secondly because I have many years of governance experience that I can use to help guide the council, and I want to contribute to Canterbury being a very good place to live and work, now and in the future.

candidates.name: Phil Driver
candidates.why_elect: I have in-depth scientific knowledge of climate science and water management coupled with extensive business, governance and management experience in government, the private sector and the charitable sector. I have particular expertise in facilitating large-scale public sector strategies.
candidates.why_stand: I'm hugely frustrated that the 1st order priorities of the Canterbury Water Management Strategy have not been achieved over the last 10 years. I will drive ECAN to do much better.

candidates.name: Peter McIlraith
candidates.why_elect: Large bureaucracies with huge rate rises and centralised power has tainted the notion of "local solutions to local issues." I am standing for Environment Canterbury because I have the knowledge and experience to correct that damage.
candidates.why_stand: South Canterbury and North Otago have been my home. My life has been living and working in the natural environment, in the best place in the world to live.

candidates.name: Elizabeth McKenzie
candidates.why_elect: I will bring a more progressive voice to ECan, and a female perspective. I have demonstrated leadership in both academic and voluntary sectors, and I see my diverse science background as an advantage, enabling me to employ an integrated, holistic approach required for dealing with complex social and environmental systems.
candidates.why_stand: I had gotten to a point in my life where the state of the planet became more urgent and important to me than anything else I was doing. In my academic role I saw that simply producing more evidence was having no effect on political decision-making.

candidates.name: Roy Knight
candidates.why_elect: I have a vast knowledge and successes in business management, a strong understanding of good governance and leadership. I have no political ties so no hidden agendas or puppet strings to be pulled. I will shake up the hornet's nest to get results if necessary.
candidates.why_stand: Born and raised in my electorate and still living there now I've seen the degradation of a once clean and green region, my total loss of faith in a system we call ECan has led me to make a stand for change.

candidates.name: Tane Apanui
candidates.why_elect: I'm the practical person required at the table to prevent career politicians going off on vanity or impractical projects.
candidates.why_stand: Canterbury is an amazing region. It now needs practical people building its infrastructure. I feel that current leadership is disconnected from reality and the average person. I want Cantabrians to be happy and confident, that's not what we have right now.

candidates.name: Iaean Cranwell
candidates.why_elect: I am a pragmatic, open-minded person that values family and community. I am of Ngāi Tahu and Welsh descent, and I love living in the North East. I have an ability for bringing people together in a mutually respectful way that ensures real progress.
candidates.why_stand: I believe I can contribute to Environment Canterbury, and provide vision, strategy and leadership that will influence the shape and feel of Christchurch and Canterbury. I believe Canterbury needs an advocate and an urban voice to oversee the long term management and protection of our special freshwater resources and aquifers.

candidates.name: Jenny Hughey
candidates.why_elect: I was born in Canterbury and am passionate to turn around the level of water and nitrate pollution. I bring high level of knowledge and qualifications in public law and council decision making having advised elected Councillors at city level for many years.
candidates.why_stand: I believe I cannot sit around passively in the face of environmental pollution and water degradation. I want to work towards a paradigm shift in our culture to put the health of our people and our planet first. To take transformative local action to assist our planet.

candidates.name: Paul McMahon
candidates.why_elect: I grew up and live in a working-class community, and I have worked serving those same communities throughout my adult life. I was twice-elected to a community board (2010-2016), serving the second term as Chair, and have a background in the community sector.
candidates.why_stand: After 9 years without democracy and facing tremendous challenges of climate change etc. I want to do my part to make a difference for the city and region I love. We don't have much time and so I didn't feel I could sit this one out.

candidates.name: Lan Pham
candidates.why_elect: My background is in freshwater ecology and environmental management. I'm the Founder of Working Waters Trust, dedicated to conservation of endangered native fish. The majority of ECan this last term was firmly for the status-quo. This new council offers the opportunity for transformational change. I'm ready to lead this change.
candidates.why_stand: My drive for being your Councillor is simple—to prioritise the 'common good' of both current and future generations, where the fundamentals of clean, safe drinking water, a stable climate, swimmable rivers and an ecologically resilient environment are placed above corporate greed and profit from pollution.

candidates.name: Felicity Price
candidates.why_elect: I have a record of getting great results to benefit the Christchurch community, which has always been at the heart of what I've done—like leading the restoration of the arts centre and saving the court theatre after the earthquake destroyed its home. Plus I'm a former ECan staffer.
candidates.why_stand: I know the ward well—it's where I went to school, it's where my children grew up, where my office was based and where I still live today. I'm well aware of the issues the ward faces and I'm committed to seeing an environmental turnaround.

candidates.name: Axel Wilke
candidates.why_elect: I'm a transport specialist with long-standing involvement in community issues. I'm a leader in innovation and bringing parties together. My understanding of political process across local, regional and national levels means I can lead urgently needed change at ECan. I'm passionate about ending our reliance on fossil fuels in transport.
candidates.why_stand: In 2018 I had a wake-up call and believe it's time for moving beyond self-interest. I'm committed to taking decisive action for the 'common good', prioritising a healthy, viable future for our kids and grandkids above all else. Transport is key to this, and we need a specialist on council.

candidates.name: Alan Chow
candidates.why_elect: I was raised in Ashburton and moved to Christchurch to complete my degree at the University of Canterbury. Christchurch is home for over 20 years. I have senior management and governance experience at Non-For-Profit organisations. I am currently a Board Member and Treasurer of Forest and Bird NZ.
candidates.why_stand: Canterbury is Home. I believe we can all do our bit for a better tomorrow. My motivation is for my children to enjoy a cleaner and greener Canterbury. I will be your eyes and ears to ensure all ratepayers money is spent efficiently and effectively.

candidates.name: Evan Harris
candidates.why_elect: Coming from running a significant family business for forty years, I understand the importance of extracting value for money in all that we do. Even more important when it is community money.
candidates.why_stand: Born, educated and worked in Canterbury all my life. Now retired from active business and have both time and enthusiasm to contribute to improving the environment back to what it was two generations ago, that is can swim and drink from rivers.

candidates.name: Nicole Marshall
candidates.why_elect: I'm a groundwater scientist who has worked in local government. I have intimate understanding of issues facing our natural resources, and more importantly, I have practical ideas to address these. I will listen to my community and respond to their concerns. I will be visible and accessible across my term.
candidates.why_stand: Because I'm sick of inaction regarding the degraded state of our environment and inaction in adapting to climate change. I represent a growing disquiet in our youth; that previous generations have sacrificed our future for their financial gain. The tide needs to turn on this. Now. Before it's too late.

candidates.name: Vicky Southworth
candidates.why_elect: I've completed a Master of Water Resources from the University of Canterbury following 15 years of scientific and planning experience. I'm involved with restoration planting locally. I've advocated for biodiversity and water quality as a community representative on a regional committee gaining a sense of what works and what doesn't.
candidates.why_stand: We are faced with climate change globally, huge losses in native biodiversity nationally and nitrate and other water pollution issues locally. These things are all linked. I can bring my skills to work collaboratively to find the balance we need to prosper whilst protecting the natural resources we care about.

candidates.name: Rik Tindall
candidates.why_elect: Open and honest, I will hit the ground running based on wide, relevant experience: ECan Councillor Christchurch East 2007-10; Spreydon-Heathcote Community Board 2013-16; Christchurch Estuary Association 2009-18; Cashmere Residents' Association 2011-18; Predator Free Port Hills 2016-19 etc. Christchurch-born, six years travel away, self-employed IT professional, always volunteering eg civil defence.
candidates.why_stand: Environment-Canterbury needs help. Pressured from all sides, with competing resource uses, it can seldom make everyone happy. Indeed ECan receives the most blame, for both doing too much and never enough. So I will help hear and represent community views, bringing fair balance to decisions where this is much needed.

candidates.name: Phil Clearwater
candidates.why_elect: I have been a longstanding Community Board Chair, and a Christchurch City Councillor for two terms, chairing committees on infrastructure, transport, environment and community development. I will bring integrity, experience, skills and leadership essential for a new, democratic ECan.
candidates.why_stand: I believe we are the guardians of our environment. In Canterbury there has never been greater need to protect our pristine water which is at serious risk. The need for environmental action and transport transformation is urgent.

candidates.name: James Macbeth Dann
candidates.why_elect: I have strong connections to a number of communities, groups, and local organisations. My background in science allows me to process some of the complex information regularly presented to ECan, while my experience in the media allows me to communicate that to constituents clearly and understandably.
candidates.why_stand: ECan has lacked leadership for a decade—because the previous government sacked ECan. Now that we have a chance to elect our regional council, I want to be part of it, to bring strong environmental leadership back to the Canterbury region.

candidates.name: Hamish Keown
candidates.why_elect: I will bring a different view due to my age and experiences. I've worked in both the community and government space for a few years, and have also held a number of positions that have required me to make decisions on complex issues.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing for Environment Canterbury because I am deeply invested in the protection and enhancement of our environment and community.

candidates.name: Alexa Forbes
candidates.why_elect: I've served 2 terms on QLDC and am deeply connected with communities of the headwaters. I facilitate Leadership for Change and sustainability programmes and am a communications professional. My research explores the collision of exponential tech and exponential environmental degradation. I work towards creating better futures for community and environment.
candidates.why_stand: I want to work on the changes we need to make to solve current and looming issues. We face exponential change and degradation. The rate of our knowledge building and ability to respond needs to be similarly exponential. Intra regional cooperation, understanding and collaboration is key.

candidates.name: Phill Hunt
candidates.why_elect: I am positive, practical and approachable. I work with all team members to achieve results I don't work against them. I will bring a rural perspective to ensure that policies are workable in the rural environment. I understand the difference between governance and management.
candidates.why_stand: I want a more collaborative and open regional council with a continued focus on the environment and a respect for the economic drivers of our region. I now have the time to invest into the role of Councillor to make this happen.

candidates.name: Gary Kelliher
candidates.why_elect: I have been an ORC Councillor from 2013 to 2016. I have an open mind and willingness to listen. I make decisions based on facts and data and sound justification, not rhetoric or alternative agenda. My past experience means I can be effective immediately.
candidates.why_stand: I am very focused on playing my part in ensuring Otago has sustainable outcomes in the critical activities it will undertake in the next two terms. Balanced sensible decisions that will stand the tests of time but are considerate of climate change, environmental enhancement, and economically sustainable.

candidates.name: Richard Bowman
candidates.why_elect: I hold BSc Hons (Geology) and MBA degrees from Otago University. I have worked as Biosecurity Manager for Environment Southland for 24 years and have dealt with wilding conifers, rabbits, wallabies, freshwater pests and biodiversity threats. I combine this experience with a lifelong love of the outdoors.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing for ORC because I want to see our water, land, air and coastal resources used in sensible and sustainable ways. My aim is to ensure ORC meets both its legal obligations and communities' expectations in managing the region's natural and physical resources.

candidates.name: Alex Familton
candidates.why_elect: I have been a farmer, teacher, lecturer and local body Mayor in the Waitaki area for a lifetime. Politically I am not aligned but have worked with various parties to promote positive policies generally as they affect local people in the regions. Qualifications MNZMBScDipEd. I thrive on problem solving.
candidates.why_stand: We are a rural community with a love of land and a desire to have happy people and animals with access to healthy ecosystems, soils and water. As a member of the Eastern Rivers Otago (community) Catchment group I am determined to hand the next generation an improved sustainable biomass.

candidates.name: Kevin Malcolm
candidates.why_elect: I have experience is banking, forestry, timber company management, risk management, agriculture and horticulture, property development, local body governance, board of trustee chair, community support. I say yes when I am ready to say yes and no when no is needed. Let's get Otago being the very best possible.
candidates.why_stand: It is essential for all of us to take responsibility to ensure we deliver an exciting and sustainable future for generations to come. It is mine and my family's time to ensure that becomes a reality.

candidates.name: Gail May-Sherman
candidates.why_elect: My experience is diverse: I have degrees in mathematics and history; I have taught children and adults; I build scientific instruments. I understand complex technical material as well as human behavior. I own rural property and understand rural challenges. I will make decisions based on both science and compassion.
candidates.why_stand: I have two children and a grandchild. Climate change will alter our society dramatically in their lifetimes. I feel a moral responsibility to help create a more connected and resilient society, and therefore, a better future for us all. I believe this is still possible in Otago.

candidates.name: Lloyd McCall
candidates.why_elect: My background in compliance with Clutha Development and facilitating the Pomahaka Water Care Group and recently Otago South River Care shows an ability to get community and stakeholder engagement working together to achieve common goals. This approach achieves superior outcomes compared to heavily regulated systems.
candidates.why_stand: Otago is in my blood. Otago's dynamic landscapes and climate is perfect for pastoral farming, tourism and industry to work in harmony with each other. I am driven to ensure we maintain our uniqueness for the future generations.

candidates.name: Andrew Velman
candidates.why_elect: Nature is perfect. Why activities of humans ruin environment? This is our only living planet. Think about your impact.
candidates.why_stand: I believe Dunedin should become a capital of South Island—reducing pollution (air, water and noise pollution) will help to achieve it.

candidates.name: Kate Wilson
candidates.why_elect: I have trained in law and geography so understand the statutory framework, I have worked in communities to find grass root solutions and I am a good listener. I know that Councils make the best progress and effect on the environment working with communities.
candidates.why_stand: Because I think there is a need for change of direction at Council and having been involved in change governance at the DCC I think I have the skills to assist communities and residents to get the best change they need.

candidates.name: Robert Hamlin
candidates.why_elect: I am a) honest and b) completely feral. I cannot be bought. I have no interest in hobnobbing with the well-connected, and even less in accepting hospitality/favours from same. I loathe corruption and pinstripe-banditry in any shape or form. I am also (c) intelligent, educated, suspicious and hard to fool.
candidates.why_stand: Council costs and rates have been rising beyond inflation for some time, and show no signs of stopping. I am convinced that most of this increase can be suppressed by ensuring greater efficiency of expenditure. I have skills in analysing organisational expenditure which can be usefully applied in this role.

candidates.name: Carmen Felicity Hope (nee Knowler)
candidates.why_elect: I will continue to Listen. To be at community lead engagements, such as community board meetings, catchment days and council lead days such as the Manuhikeria, Arrow and Cardona catchment days, to understand local concerns and what is important to them. We must take them on a journey too.
candidates.why_stand: I like people and working with people to understand how our area of Molyneux ticks—both urban and rural. As a regional councillor I can assist. More than a decade was spent at the Dunedin City Council in drainage—many a coal face meetings land owners.

candidates.name: Tony Hunter
candidates.why_elect: My experience in education has provided me with a strong foundation for engaging with communities and responding to their changing needs. A school community is like a wider community. many stakeholders with various needs. if you engage well with your community, you get results people are happy with.
candidates.why_stand: My motivation for standing is to leave a positive legacy in a community that is environmentally and socially healthy and where the community feels a sense of belonging, engagement and connection with the Otago Regional Council processes.

candidates.name: Matt Kraemer
candidates.why_elect: I've designed, founded and managed a business which employed 13 people and I've had 7 years of software development experience. This combination of technical and social problem solving is somewhat unusual but valuable and necessary for fixing the public transport system.
candidates.why_stand: It bothers me that buses are empty, parking is difficult, and my local stream smells worse than a public restroom. The pay and status are better on the City Council, but I would rather make a difference where it counts, on the Otago Regional Council.

candidates.name: Tim Mepham
candidates.why_elect: I am a Chartered Accountant and Chartered Fellow of the Institute of Directors with many years of experience in the Dunedin business community. I am currently Chairman of the board of Presbyterian Support Otago, Trustee of the Yellow eyed penguin trust and also a Director of City Forests.
candidates.why_stand: I have been a fish and game licence holder for the last 30 years and over this time I have witnessed the degradation of our freshwater systems I want to be in a position to influence the restoration of clean waterways, lakes and wetlands protecting these taonga for future generations.

candidates.name: Gretchen Robertson
candidates.why_elect: I believe I offer experience and real commitment to making a difference for you. I am a qualified water quality scientist and community facilitator. I have 15 years experience on the council. I am currently deputy chairperson. I work hard and listen to our community.
candidates.why_stand: I'm a multigenerational Dunedinite. The mother of two young boys. A water quality scientist and an experienced Councillor. I love Otago, it's people and its environment. I believe it's a crucial time in local government history, a time communities expect action. I would be privileged to be part of it.

candidates.name: Andrew Rutherford
candidates.why_elect: I will try and open up the council to public scrutiny. I work from an evidence based standpoint.
candidates.why_stand: To hold the ORC to account and to have greater efficiency and transparency through a unitary organisation. Also to hold the ORC owned companies to account such as Port Otago and Chalmers Property. Secondly to do what I can to increase sustainable economic development in Dunedin.

candidates.name: Bryan Scott
candidates.why_elect: As a professional engineer, project manager and previous Regional Councillor, I believe I can make a difference. I have successfully chaired the ORC technical and regulatory committees, freshwater reference group and an accredited chair for RMA hearings. I have a track record of active and effective governance.
candidates.why_stand: Born and raised in Otago. My passions are the outdoors, tramping in the hills and family. I am concerned about the pressures on our environment both urban and rural. Utilising my background as professional engineer, project manager and previous Regional Councillor, I believe I can make a difference.

candidates.name: Scott Willis
candidates.why_elect: Over the years I've forged connections with politicians, business and education leaders, researchers, government agencies and flax-roots organisers and activists. Adaptive governance requires us to be innovative and open to change while being able to listen and work with diverse groups. This is where my real strength in governance lies.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that by working together we can deliver solutions to the climate crisis and enable future generations to thrive.
