I bring proven experience in governance, collaboration and community engagement to help ORC and our community meet the challenges ahead. Otago is unique. Let's value our place.

candidates.name: Rob Woodhouse
candidates.why_elect: I have lived on Otago my whole life, and I'm fiercely proud of our region. I have wide management experience and qualifications applicable to being your councillor. I will be a voice for all residents.
candidates.why_stand: Otago is the best province in the world, however it is starting to languish behind other more progressive regions. The ORC is sitting on assets of over $650 million dollars, that can be freed up for new investment in Otago.

candidates.name: Hilary Calvert
candidates.why_elect: I have a background in government both local and central, in business and as a lawyer. I will ask the difficult questions and not give up until the council has enough information to make good decisions. I will keep the ORC governance function grounded in reality about the issues.
candidates.why_stand: I believe the ORC is close to having a commissioner appointed because the government is losing confidence in the ORC's ability to carry out it's regulatory functions. We have a fabulous and special province, and we should be capable of looking after it ourselves.

candidates.name: Michael Deaker
candidates.why_elect: I trained as a geographer and that's ideal for regional council work. I had senior management experience in schools and public service, and I was a communications consultant. All that has help me be an effective, articulate councillor for five terms. I'm as enthusiastic and positive now as ever.
candidates.why_stand: In all my years in education, journalism, broadcasting and local government, I have been "a southerner" and very proud of it. Now we have 11 grandchildren in various parts of Otago and I want their futures to be at least as good as my life.

candidates.name: Marian Hobbs
candidates.why_elect: Largely, I understand the language of policy documents and I have the skill to translate them into words which engage the different communities in debate as to the best way forward. I enjoy and respect that engagement and continue to learn effective ways forward. I am open.
candidates.why_stand: I have unfinished business. With three young grandchildren I am determined that the Otago they may live in, will be as environmentally rich as I experienced in my youth. A regional council can make reality from my former unrealised dreams as Minister for the Environment.

candidates.name: Allan Baird
candidates.why_elect: I have a strong commercial and farming background. I have eight years on Federated Farmers Southland Executive, including three years as Provincial President. Our family are long standing Southland residents and I have two sons to whom I would desire a prosperous and positive region for their generation and future.
candidates.why_stand: Local government is an important part of our democracy and I have developed a good skill set to be of value to my community in this role.

candidates.name: Roger Hodgkinson
candidates.why_elect: I'm an ex sheep farmer, now residing in Te Anau. I'm an active advocate for coherent regional strategy and actively lobby decision makers. We must formulate/implement our own regional solutions before they are externally imposed! Our region will thrive into the future despite economic and environmental challenges.
candidates.why_stand: I am motivated to be nominated candidate for representing the Fiordland Constituency as I have moved their in the last 6 years and wish to actively contribute where I can, to help preserve both its spectacular natural environment and wildlife habitat of Fiordland National Park and adjoining farming region.

candidates.name: Gemma Mcgrath
candidates.why_elect: I'm all about collaboration and working together to progress people, alongside regenerating the health of our natural environment. I'll serve you well, as I'm good at understanding multiple peoples' perspectives, as well as the science. I have qualifications and experience in science communication and marine conservation.
candidates.why_stand: I'm standing to represent you and our environment—our greatest community asset. I love the land, and the waterways that surround us. We need to improve the state of our environment for our future and our children.

candidates.name: Sera Perham
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in almost every city of New Zealand except for Auckland. What attracted my family to Nightcaps is the spirit of counter-urbanisation; lifestyle, affordability, community spirit of looking out for each other. I have the time for my community, to ask questions and keeping everyone informed.
candidates.why_stand: Our rural community is expanding. We need thinkers who can express community voices clearly at regional council meetings. We need thinkers who can interrogate regional policies that are fundamentally fair to all parties. Importantly, we need thinkers who believe in local knowledge while respecting each others differences.

candidates.name: Robert Guyton
candidates.why_elect: The people of Southland who feel they are represented most effectively by me, are a very wide and varied group, many of whom do not share significant values or aspirations with the more conservative councillors. I provide them an opportunity for active and confident representation.
candidates.why_stand: I've been doing what I said I would do for 9 years on council; fronting-up to difficult issues and bringing them to the forefront of council thinking and I will continue to do that for another term if re-elected.

candidates.name: Bonnie Mager
candidates.why_elect: I have a scientific background, and I believe my knowledge and passion for Southland will provide valuable knowledge to the council. As a digital native, I have the passion and skills to engage with our community in the online arena, making me easy to contact and chat to.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about our natural environment, and I want to see someone who truly represents people in my generation.

candidates.name: Bruce Pagan
candidates.why_elect: I have a sound background in leadership and governance. Previous stints in local government with Bluff and Invercargill City Council and with various community groups has given me a practical insight into getting things done!
candidates.why_stand: I want to be part of the decision making process that does its best to preserve our environment and its resources for future generations—that we take the necessary steps so that people can continue to enjoy Southland as a cool place to live and work.

candidates.name: Eric Roy
candidates.why_elect: Wisdom experience and governance.
candidates.why_stand: Southland is my home and the place I value It's where I treasure every experience particularly the outdoors I want to see my grandchildren have a safe and beautiful place to grow up.

candidates.name: Nathan Surendran
candidates.why_elect: My career includes working as a Chartered Professional Engineer and entrepreneur. I've been involved in small business as a retrofit glazing installer and at various events with my mobile juice bar. I'm a co-founder of the 'Love Local' charitable trust. I engage with council consultations proactively.
candidates.why_stand: I'm a 41-year-old father, tertiary educator and proud Southland resident. I believe in light of climate change and resource depletion trends, Southland has very attractive fundamentals. I'm committed to leaving the world a better place for my children, and believe regional level action is key.

candidates.name: Lloyd Esler
candidates.why_elect: I've always had a practical involvement with the Southland community. I know the key issues and the people associated with them. I'm accessible, hands on and well-informed.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that Southland is the best part of NZ. We have big issues here and I have lots to contribute as someone with council experience and for my involvement with tourism, education and environmental projects.

candidates.name: Shaun Curtis
candidates.why_elect: Good governance enables our valued DHB staff to care for our communities effectively. I can bring the requisite skills and experience to deliver this, along with some fresh thinking. Everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect, and I will ensure people are forefront in my thoughts and actions.
candidates.why_stand: I'm standing for the future of our healthcare—I believe fresh and vibrant thinking will be a welcome addition in the boardroom. I am passionate about ensuring the quality of life for all Northlanders, and our health is crucial to this.

candidates.name: Kyle Eggleton
candidates.why_elect: I am a seventh generation Northlander and have worked as a rural general practitioner in Northland for 16 year. I sit on numerous international, national and local health governance committees. In addition I am a Senior Lecturer at the University of Auckland and research quality health care.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about ensuring that people can get the health care that they need and deserve. Unfortunately Northland has some of the worse health statistics in NZ despite living in one of the best places in NZ. All Northlanders are therefore entitled to the very best health care.

candidates.name: Libby Jones
candidates.why_elect: For 30 years I have worked in health and social services in clinical, leadership and funding roles. Currently I am the Manager of Jigsaw North Family Services assisting children and families in Whangarei. I have 18 years governance experience across health, education, social services, rural and local government.
candidates.why_stand: As a current director on NDHB I know that while we are seeing positive health improvements, it is not enough and we need to keep our focus on prevention of ill health, working together more effectively and timely access to quality health services for all.

candidates.name: Sally Macauley
candidates.why_elect: I have been an elected member for the last 18 years with a three year chairmanship of NDHB Community, Public Health and Disabilities and 6 years Deputy Chairman. I have a commerce and finance background. I foremost believe the health and safety of our workforce being imperative.
candidates.why_stand: As Chairman for the last 3 years I've lead a team that has successfully governed and overseen the health and welfare of Northland within available resources. It is imperative we effectively engage with the local Māori Stakeholders.

candidates.name: Carol Peters
candidates.why_elect: I'm a flax-roots community development worker who supports people to lift the wellbeing of their own communities. I participated in setting up a community health centre, community law, and housing projects. I am experienced at listening to people's problems, so will advocate for our health system to be more responsive.
candidates.why_stand: From my work, I see the very serious health requirements some local people have, especially when they are ageing, have poor housing, cannot afford good food. I wish to promote joined-up health services that address the causes of poor health, with resources and appropriate staff to meet these needs.

candidates.name: John Bain
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Northland for 46 years and have been involved with several charities most of which I have Chaired in part. The most publicly visible is the building of world class and envied patient retrieval system both on road and helicopter. I am a manager who gets things done.
candidates.why_stand: I am a current Board member and have knowledge from Ambulance and Helicopter background that serves me well on the DHB. We are in a time of change with treatments and science and I feel I can contribute to this world to the advantage of all Northlanders.

candidates.name: Bill Bradford
candidates.why_elect: I have spent many years managing not for profit GP and dental services and a PHO providing services for low income people. I have also worked in public health. I believe elected DHB members have a duty to ensure the voice of local communities is heard at all political levels.
candidates.why_stand: I have always loved Northland but have never been able to accept the levels of poverty, disadvantage and exclusion that are part of the lives of too many residents. Quality primary health care and bold public health initiatives can make a difference. We can do a lot better.

candidates.name: John Vujcich
candidates.why_elect: I'm a strategic and critical thinker with a strong background in science and technology and have governance and business experience. I'm born in the Hokianga, understand the culture and challenges we face and have the desire to improve general health statistics of all our people. I represent rural/urban Northland.
candidates.why_stand: I want to see everyone, especially our rural people, have improved access to good quality local health services. I'm offended by the poor health statistics and believe improved wellbeing can be achieved by all organisations across all sectors taking into account the health implications of their decisions.

candidates.name: Harko Brown
candidates.why_elect: I have worked long and hard with many other people and organisations in Northland, especially around youth mental health initiatives, to uplift and upskill our future generations so I am not a 'come-lately', I always have my sleeves rolled-up. I am a specialist educator with masters, honours and conjoint degrees.
candidates.why_stand: I have skills and networks which can benefit the health provision of Northlanders. Mental health issues are huge and we need to address those with cultural understandings which I can help to facilitate. We have a beautiful region and amazing people—let's work for the best health options.

candidates.name: Sophia Xiao-Colley
candidates.why_elect: My life journey has had a lot of ups and downs, and there have been some useful lessons for me. My motto is: love yourself, do your best, enjoy life as a learning journey, master the art of balance.
candidates.why_stand: I am thankful for the support I have received as a refugee from China. My husband and our 6-year-old daughter are supporting me to pay back our community. I genuinely believe that there is healing power within the human body's ecosystem.

candidates.name: Jeffrey Burson
candidates.why_elect: I have the financial skills to help achieve the above. In addition I have friends and family that work with the DHB across all levels to feed back and ensure what we are doing at board level is making a difference.
candidates.why_stand: Our front line staff throughout Northland do an amazing job with the resources they have available. I want to provide sound governance to the organisation so these staff can continue their work, ideally with additional resources.

candidates.name: Steve Capper
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Whangarei for all but 2 years of my life. I have a wealth of business knowledge from running my own business and being a senior manager in one of Whangarei's largest manufacturers. I have a community focused awareness and want to help our community thrive.
candidates.why_stand: Northland Is a fantastic place to live, and we need to ensure we are providing the services required by our aging and growing population. We are to heavily reliant on specialist service support from regions outside of Northland. I wish to improve this and increase funding for us all.

candidates.name: Vince Cocurullo
candidates.why_elect: As a WDC Councillor, I believe in strong governance and management. I listen, and deal with issues as they happen, however I also believe in getting people to help themselves. As a business person, I believe in making sure my clients are looked after, the NDHB should be the same.
candidates.why_stand: As a successful local business person for the past 20 years, I have been seeing the growth within our district, however our hospitals and medical services are not keeping up with the demands on them. I believe in being proactive, rather than reactive.

candidates.name: Monina Hernandez
candidates.why_elect: I make things happen. I have governance experience in public and not-for-profit roles in the New Zealand Nurses Organisation and in the Nursing Council – authority responsible for protecting public health and safety. I have 27 years' experience as community nurse, women's health/paediatric nurse, infection control specialist and academic.
candidates.why_stand: I worked in WDHB as a nurse specialist, loved engaging with patients and am a member of its community. I believe WDHB services can still be improved. I can help with these improvements through hard work. My work ethic is driven by values of industry, integrity, fairness, caring, respect and excellence.

candidates.name: Jono Hoogerbrug
candidates.why_elect: On a daily basis, I see first hand where we succeed and fail at delivering care. I have also been involved in academic research and healthcare innovation. I will take my experience across the health sector to bring a fresh, collaborative and thoughtful approach to the board.
candidates.why_stand: Being a GP who’s worked throughout WDHB, I have the unique privilege of helping a diverse range of Kiwis with their healthcare needs. With this experience, I am standing to lead an innovative approach at WDHB to ensure our communities receive the high-quality accessible healthcare they deserve.

candidates.name: Allison Roe
candidates.why_elect: I have a lifetime interest in human performance and what makes us healthy, partly through being an athlete. Six years in local government has connected me closely with my community and provided a real understanding of local health needs and wants.
candidates.why_stand: I am standing because our health system is all about finding and controlling disease with 99 % of resources focused away from providing true prevention, cure and much needed education to keep people healthy in their communities. I will work towards a seismic shift in that paradigm.

candidates.name: Pete Tashkoff
candidates.why_elect: I am an expert in management and IT systems. Our healthcare system has many opportunities for systems improvement. Every constraint we remove frees up money for clinical outcomes. Many fine people standing will focus on the clinical outcomes, my focus is finding them the money to do it.
candidates.why_stand: I want to apply my expertise in systems management to make the systems involved in healthcare work better and faster, freeing up scare resources for the benefit of professionals and patients.

candidates.name: Lindsay Waugh
candidates.why_elect: My local Government experience has shaped my collaborative and incisive style which has resulted in many gains for the local community. I believe this same approach will bring a fresh people focused perspective to the delivery of health services.
candidates.why_stand: As the inaugural Chair of the Kaipātiki Local Board and after 12 years in local government i have decided to re- focus to apply my community and governance experience to seek election to the Waitematā District Health Board which serves the area that has been my home for 40 years.

candidates.name: Zahra Champion
candidates.why_elect: I am a empathic leader with the skillset and desire to make a difference for our community. As the Chair of Hearing Auckland, board member Asthma NZ, both organisations deal with health disparities, as we educate communities most in need to access the support required to live a healthy life.
candidates.why_stand: West Auckland is my home, watching the infilling of houses on our productive land we call this progression, but the disparity between my community widen, this is not progression. I want to see our people having access to services to enable them to live their lives to the fullest.

candidates.name: Uzra Casouri-Balouch
candidates.why_elect: I approach this role with an attitude of service. I am an accredited Justice of Peace, a Treaty People Facilitator and a prudent financial manager who will actively seek your views and preferences when making decisions. I pledge to be accessible, available and your strong local voice at the WDHB.
candidates.why_stand: A vote for me is a vote for a local, experienced and passionate voice for WDHB area residents. I love this community and I have been working hard here in governance roles for 17 years, the last three as an elected member of the Upper Harbour Local Board, Auckland Council.

candidates.name: Tricia Cheel
candidates.why_elect: Lived in Waitemata area for 42 years. Setting up my practice as a Classical Homoeopath in 1987 I found the same people came to me, with the same symptoms, every time the council sprayed carcinogenic glyphosate in their area. My efforts to remove the cause now extend to the DHB.
candidates.why_stand: I am concerned that I only get offered one drug, or another, rather than simple things that can solve my problem, without running the risks of inevitable side-effects all pharmaceuticals have, and I want to leave no stone unturned to ensure that everyone can have their treatment of choice.

candidates.name: Edward Benson-Cooper
candidates.why_elect: As a current board member, I have intimate knowledge of the role and bring much-needed governance and business experience. With an understanding of policy and the legislative environment, I wish to continue the critical work we have started and provide innovative representation.
candidates.why_stand: Seeking re-election for the WDHB—I have been involved in making great strides with future infrastructure projects and community programmes. My interest is to continue this great work and to make a positive impact to the lives of the people in the Waitemata community. I will champion meaningful change.

candidates.name: Lynne Coleman
candidates.why_elect: I have a Fellowship in General Practice and Urgent Care. I have governance experience from community and national organisations. I am a Chartered Member of the Institute of Directors. In 2015 I was honoured with MNZM for my work in health and sport.
candidates.why_stand: I have worked as a doctor in Waitemata for over 30 years. I live in this community. I want to represent you all. I will use all my knowledge, connections and experience to improve how Waitemata DHB responds and delivers services.

candidates.name: Sandra Coney
candidates.why_elect: I've got a lot of experience in health and bring a strong consumer perspective to the Board. My background is in community women's health and I have a QSO for my services. I believe strongly in ensuring communities have a voice and are heard.
candidates.why_stand: I have had three terms on Waitemata DHB and want to continue working to improve health care for people of the north and west. We've made a lot of progress but there's still a job to do.

candidates.name: Nathan Billing
candidates.why_elect: I am a health professional and have worked at WDHB and within the New Zealand health sector for over ten years. I have governance experience and international experiences of other health systems. I know what great health services look like, and want to deliver the best care for everyone.
candidates.why_stand: Waitemata District Health Board serves the largest population in the country and is one of the most innovative. I believe I can make a meaningful contribution to the board and to my community. I want to ensure our hospital services are futureproof.

candidates.name: Warren William Flaunty
candidates.why_elect: I have a wealth of intellectual knowledge to ensure WDHB continues to be well represented, making informed, sensible and disciplined decisions on behalf of your community. I believe I have the drive, experience and enthusiasm to continue to be an effective Board member. Improved services for Rodney a priority.
candidates.why_stand: Pharmacist, current elected Board Member. Proud to have been involved with major decisions of WDHB over the past 18 years creating NZ's leading DHB with world class facilities, medical staff and volunteers. New initiatives include a second tower at North Shore Hospital and an upgrade of Waitakere Hospital.

candidates.name: Claire Buckley
candidates.why_elect: I am an outstanding communicator. I work with the College of Surgeons in communication training and I believe that being able to communicate needs of the DHB to central government is a key skill I can bring to the table. Also, I'm tenacious.
candidates.why_stand: I am running after spending 18 months advocating for my father's health through the WDHB system and finding my family and I frustrated at every turn. It should not be difficult for a patient and their family to get answers and positive outcomes from a hospital.

candidates.name: Kullasit Chutipongpisit
candidates.why_elect: As a front line-clinician, I believe that I truly understand the needs and challenges in which a DHB faces when it comes to delivering care to our patients. Combined with my clinical and previous governance experiences, I would like to represent and advocate for both patients and clinicians.
candidates.why_stand: I feel that more front-line clinicians should be represented on DHBs as we truly understand the real needs and resources required to successfully and efficiently deliver care to our patients.

candidates.name: Tadhg Tim Stopford
candidates.why_elect: This is a critical time for healthcare. We are failing to improve chronic age related and lifestyle conditions, and they are bankrupting us. I am at the cutting edge of evidence based medicine, and am well placed to lead/educate ADHB into improved health outcomes and reduced costs.
candidates.why_stand: I wrote NZs first recognised cannabis course for RNZCGPs, and have taught 650 medical professionals Hemp Medicine since then. A sitting ADHB Board member has nominated me, because her MS related pain and fatigue has been improved with hemp. Hemp is the future of medicine, but it's unknown to most.

candidates.name: Patrick Cummuskey
candidates.why_elect: I'm able to contribute my experience as a volunteer ambulance officer, chair of the St John Central Auckland Area Committee and a regulatory building official, along with other skills drawn from my involvement in civil defence and the engineering community to bring a broad spectrum of knowledge to the ADHB.
candidates.why_stand: I've volunteered with St John Ambulance for over a decade and seen many parts of the health sector and the people it takes care of. I want to step up further and contribute my time and experience to making every improvement I can to improve our population health.

candidates.name: Peter Davis
candidates.why_elect: I have used the media, so I can articulate positions. I have been elected before to the hospital board and regional council, so I am aware of the responsibilities. I have lived in the area for most of my adult life, so I know it well.
candidates.why_stand: I have spent a career studying health policy and health systems, and so now is a chance to offer that expertise to the sector.

candidates.name: Pete Williams
candidates.why_elect: Aside from dealing with and understanding the ADHB as a patient, I am passionate about 'ambulance at the top of the cliff' policies. I have worked nationally and internationally for the last 20 years in the medical sector. Currently I am also on the board of Parafed Auckland.
candidates.why_stand: I am wheelchair bound, have had over 50 operations and spent close to 10% of my life in a hospital environment. I am standing, whilst sitting, to ensure all Aucklanders feel safe, informed and supported in their medical care.

candidates.name: Susan Fleming
candidates.why_elect: I am passionate about good healthcare. I have a deep understanding of our healthcare system nationally and locally. I feel deeply connected to Auckland—where I grew up and was educated. I have the experience to ensure ADHB delivers care responsibly and in a way that matters to you.
candidates.why_stand: My life has been devoted to healthcare. As an Obstetrician and Gynaecologist I could make a difference one patient at a time. As a senior Women's Health leader I could influence a service. As a board member I could use my skills and experience to improve the health of Aucklanders.

candidates.name: Jo Agnew
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in the healthcare sector as a registered nurse in different roles for 35 years and feel that I have a considerable amount of experience to share.
candidates.why_stand: The reason for me standing as a member of the Auckland District Health Board is that I feel strongly about the health of our population and I want to be involved in planning for future.

candidates.name: Adam Amos
candidates.why_elect: I've lived in Auckland all my life, and I know I'm being optimistic by saying "when I'm elected..." but when I'm elected to the Auckland DHB, I know without a doubt that any input that I have on the Auckland DHB, will definitely have a positive impact.
candidates.why_stand: I have a strong passion for high quality, first class, general healthcare, and I would like to see positive changes within the aged care sector. A single transferable vote (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7) for me will not go wrong.

candidates.name: Kerrin Leoni
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in the local community for more than 10 years and have 19 years experience as a social worker, manager and now a government funding manager. I am Co-Chair and Board member of Violent Free Communities and Founder of Charitable organisation Mana Aroha providing global opportunities for youth.
candidates.why_stand: I believe Auckland is one of the best cities in the world and therefore we should have world class healthcare which meets the needs of the people. Healthy whānau and healthy families is a key priority for me which means prevention is of great importance.

candidates.name: Douglas Armstrong
candidates.why_elect: I have served on the Board and its Finance and health subcommittees for 2 terms and have demonstrated an effective governance contribution in that time.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that Auckland deserves world class healthcare and that I have the governance and experience needed on the Board to further this objective.

candidates.name: Kyle Macdonald
candidates.why_elect: I'm a psychotherapist with 20 years experience, 10 working for DHBs; I'm also Chair of the Board of the Key to Life Charitable Trust, the charity behind the work of Mike King; on the Psychotherapists Board of Aotearoa New Zealand as well as the Board of Trustees of Balmoral School.
candidates.why_stand: My stated mission in standing for the Auckland District Health Board is to take my ten years of advocating for better access to mental health services to the DHB, and in doing so work to make good mental health care more available for all Aucklanders.

candidates.name: Michelle Atkinson
candidates.why_elect: I have spent eight years in the health sector in mental health and research, and have a PGDip Health Service Management. I have personal experience with health services and have won awards for my work. I am a current ADHB Board Member and Deputy Chair of the Hospital Advisory Committee.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about strong healthcare governance in order to improve the system, and ensure that health services are appropriate, accessible, and safe. This is inspired by my eight years' work in the sector and informed by my own experiences using health services.

candidates.name: Ross Boswell
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in the public hospital system for 40 years, and have some understanding of primary care through my advocacy for general practice as a former Chairman of the NZMA. I am committed to the promotion of good health, and the provision of health care to those in need.
candidates.why_stand: During years of working in the health system I have grown increasingly impatient for change that would make it more responsive. While individual carers are supportive and sympathetic, the system as a whole is often inflexible and impersonal. Through participation in governance I hope I can help to improve that.

candidates.name: Zoe Brownlie
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in health for the last 15 years, in governance, management, and with patients. I'm friendly, innovative, not afraid to speak up, bring fresh ideas, and listen and represent the views of all Aucklanders.
candidates.why_stand: I’m standing to be re-elected onto the Auckland District Health Board as I’ve sat on the board for the last three years, have worked in healthcare for the last 15 years, and want to use my experience and skills, along with my passion, to keep improving healthcare for all Aucklanders.

candidates.name: Glyn Richards
candidates.why_elect: I have had extensive experience in medical practice in NZ and before that in UK and Sweden.
candidates.why_stand: I have had the privilege to work for ADHD for 45 years and wish to further assist in its progress since retiring.

candidates.name: Te Karere Scarborough
candidates.why_elect: Having spent 15 years in the charity sector here in Auckland, that has included supporting all types of whānau through advocacy, education and more recently, in a general management role at Parenting Place. I believe I'm a suitable candidate because I'm accountability to my whānau first, which keeps me grounded.
candidates.why_stand: Our healthcare system is similar to the life blood of our city. However, as a Māori male I've experienced the good, and especially the negative side of that system. I didn't see a young, proud Māori father on the board. So I'm putting my hand up as a representative.

candidates.name: Bernadette Pereira
candidates.why_elect: More quality care by clinicians who treat us and engage with us. A trained workforce in cultural awareness and understanding of the diversity of populations An integral part training is understanding the essential components of empathy and compassion in communication delivered by public health staff that transcends cultural differences.
candidates.why_stand: Improved Hospital and Primary Care services especially for vulnerable communities, Māori and Pacific. Identifying what needs fixing immediately.

candidates.name: Colleen Brown
candidates.why_elect: I chair a number of organisations, locally and regionally. I have years of governance experience as a Manukau City Councillor which is important for this position. I know my community, along with the disability sector and I have sound communication and organisational skills that are critical around the Board table.
candidates.why_stand: I have lived in the Counties Manukau region virtually all my life. It is a vibrant energetic community. I live in one of the last urban forests in NZ. All our adult children, including our disabled son live in Counties Manukau as well.

candidates.name: Ray Pitch
candidates.why_elect: I have the skills, experience and passion to make the necessary changes, I have managed multi-million dollar projects, served as an Ambulance Officer in South Auckland, with a Masters Degree in Business, a Medical Degree and Emergency Management qualifications.
candidates.why_stand: As an Ambulance Officer, Red Cross worker and Cancer Society volunteer, I have seen our system fail those who need it most. 36% of the population live in poverty, they, and our aged are unable to access affordable healthcare... It angers me... I intend to fix it.

candidates.name: Katrina Bungard
candidates.why_elect: I currently work in a range of governance and management roles in health and education. I hold several qualifications including masters in educational leadership, management and policy. I am a current member of the Community and Public Health Advisory, the Auckland Regional Disability Advisory and the Māori Health Advisory committees.
candidates.why_stand: I am a current DHB member, cancer survivor and amputee; and have an acute awareness of the issues surrounding our health and disability sectors. I am a strong advocate for community health and disability, and want to ensure adequate provision of disability services and connections between health and social services.

candidates.name: Adrienne Priday
candidates.why_elect: I bring genuine health care experience grounded in the community and hospitals of Counties Manukau. I champion real outcomes through my proven leadership in health governance. My focus is on achieving quality health services and I will achieve these outcomes through advocacy for the communities I live and work in.
candidates.why_stand: My life's work is in advocating for health and wellbeing in our community. As a DHB member, I believe I could use my 24 years' experience in healthcare, governance and community health to contribute to the development of a higher standard of wellbeing for everyone in Counties Manukau region.

candidates.name: Ashraf Choudhary
candidates.why_elect: I have huge wealth of experience in research and development, tertiary education, and decision-making at both central and local government levels.
candidates.why_stand: I wish we provide best health services for our diverse population.

candidates.name: Ezekiel Robson
candidates.why_elect: Manurewa has always been my permanent home, where I attended local schools; an upbringing that drives me to serve my community. I would bring fresh energy, a collaborative approach, governance board experience, strategic thinking and analysis skills, a passion for community advocacy, and broad networks to the DHB role.
candidates.why_stand: We deserve elected leaders who better reflect the communities they represent. DHB members lack some diversity of thought and experience. I am particularly concerned about under representation of disabled people like myself, in leadership roles. This leads to our human rights and needs being ignored and neglected by decision-makers.

candidates.name: Nivedita Sharma Vij
candidates.why_elect: As NZ Registered health care professional with healthcare experience of 24 years, well aware of the accessibility, affordability and long term health issues faced by people living in the CMDHB area. Aiming for value-for-money, effective resource management and quality decision-making that puts patients and families at the heart of everything.
candidates.why_stand: I fundamentally believe that optimal, safe and timely health service is every human's right and strongly in the power of people to transform their lives. As Gandhi said "You may never know what results come of your actions, but if you do nothing, there will be no results."

candidates.name: Lorna Dyall
candidates.why_elect: I have had experience in governance at Crown director level and also involvement in senior management and policy development developing health and related programs, legislation and policy development.
candidates.why_stand: To make a difference in supporting the development of diverse peoples who live in Counties Manukau. I whakapapa to this area and have spent my health career in public health and Māori health development.

candidates.name: Catherine Abel-Pattinson
candidates.why_elect: I have lived most of my life in South Auckland either on a farm, or urban areas and I understand each area has different healthcare needs. I love the landscape, parks, beaches, the people and cultures which makes South Auckland a vibrant place in NZ.
candidates.why_stand: As a current CMDHB Director, I have worked on the wards at Middlemore hospital as a nurse, as well as over 17 years as an Executive Officer and Board Director in private and public hospitals, eldercare and primary care.

candidates.name: Dianne Glenn
candidates.why_elect: I have lived and worked in Franklin most of my life, teaching and managing adult education, then representing Franklin and Papakura at the ARC for 12 yrs, knowing these communities through meeting them at a local level. I have proven to be dedicated and committed to represent them.
candidates.why_stand: I have served the CMH District for 6 years with highest attendance rates. I am well read and informed about health and disability issues and wish to continue with the recent progress being made in addressing the serious health issues in this very culturally diverse community.

candidates.name: Apulu Reece Autagavaia
candidates.why_elect: I come from a working-class family. My parents' hard work allowed me to get a good education. I was blessed to have practiced as a lawyer and have held many community and leadership positions. I am also a proud father. I offer my skills and experience to serve our community.
candidates.why_stand: I was born and bred in South Auckland—Middlemore Hospital to be precise. This is where my family live, where I work, where I play. I want to see our people prosper and live to their potential. This includes leading healthy lives. I want to ensure that happens.

candidates.name: Autagavaia Vaaiga Autagavaia
candidates.why_elect: My Samoan culture and Christian faith drive me to serve our families and communities and ensure we thrive in every sense of the word. My medical experience gives me insight and skills to advocate for our community and ensure we get the healthcare our community deserves—the very best.
candidates.why_stand: Our South Auckland communities face many challenges, including in health. We remain resilient, trying to do the best for our families and community. I have the passion and skills as a Pacific doctor who grew up, lives and works locally to ensure CMDHB does its best for our South Auckland.

candidates.name: Anita Keestra
candidates.why_elect: Long term resident of Manukau, serves as JP, actively involved in Health/Wellbeing Advisory groups and member of the Council's Ethnic Peoples Advisory Panel. Past President of life vision society which distributes food and basic necessities to underprivileged. Holds a MBA, B.Ed and years of governance, strategic, management and business experience.
candidates.why_stand: My vision is to remove disparities in current healthcare services, ensuring accessibility, fairness and service equality to the Multicultural and Diverse population, including Māori and Pacific People. I am passionate and committed to empower women who are victims of domestic violence and are at greater risk of mental health problems.

candidates.name: Kathy Maxwell
candidates.why_elect: Having been a previous Elected Member I have sound governance experience that means I can make a valid contribution as soon as I am elected.
candidates.why_stand: As a Community Pharmacist I believe I have an understanding of how the complex health system affects patients and the challenges they face.

candidates.name: TeRata Rangi Pihoihoi Boldy
candidates.why_elect: Governance and management experience in Counties Manukau and internationally also. Work well in teams and in help teams to cooperate.
candidates.why_stand: To reduce inequalities in Māori health, to raise my voice for better mental health and effective suicide prevention.

candidates.name: Elizabeth Norman
candidates.why_elect: I hold a Bachelor of Science in Biology, a Postgraduate Diploma in Dietetics, and was registered with the Health and Care Professions Council (UK). I currently work in quality improvement in NZ hospitals. I have worked at Middlemore Hospital and want our DHB to provide quality care to our residents.
candidates.why_stand: My experience as a patient has convinced me that I need to serve as a member of Counties Manukau DHB. I have the confidence to challenge poor decision making and will ask the difficult questions to ensure our communities get the best services available.

candidates.name: Johan Morreau
candidates.why_elect: I've spent my working life in Senior Health roles, medical and administrative in the Lakes community (36 years) and understand what it takes to achieve the goals stated above.
candidates.why_stand: I want us all to be proud of the health services we deliver and the initiatives we lead. I want to be confident that Health does all it can to reduce Inequity.

candidates.name: Lyall Thurston
candidates.why_elect: A lifetime experience in health and disability having a son born with a profound physical disability.
candidates.why_stand: A longstanding passion and commitment to ensuring all have access to an enhanced publicly funded health system. Utilising experiences as a public health lobbyist and activist.

candidates.name: Jean Batt
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Rotorua for 40 years and worked at LDHB for 23 yrs. In this time. I have seen and experienced some of the inequalities and inequities, for this reason I have developed skills to be a competent candidate to sit on boards like LDHB.
candidates.why_stand: I believe our hospital is one of the best DHBs in Aotearoa. Because we are friendly, we manaaki-welcome visitors, whakawhānaungatanga new and old employers, we also have great lakes, mountains and some of the best biking and hiking tracks in NZ that attracts employment into LDHB.

candidates.name: Aroha Bray
candidates.why_elect: I've lived in my community my whole life and have worked in several areas of the hospital as well as out in the community in health roles. I have also gained 6 years political experience as an MP Electorate Agent for the district.
candidates.why_stand: Our district is very special and steeped in multicultural ways. We need to capture all the cultures that reside within our boundaries and embrace them so that they feel included in the hospital setting. I would invite speakers to represent their individual communities and tell us what they need.

candidates.name: Stuart Burns
candidates.why_elect: This district has been my home for a long time and I have a good understanding of our community. I am a current Board member. I have the qualifications along with professional governance and management experience to continue to play a key role in the governance of the Lakes DHB.
candidates.why_stand: Rotorua has been my home for most of my life, and I have always had an active interest in supporting the community and organisations by using my professional skills to provide strength and positive outcomes.

candidates.name: Olive Gallagher
candidates.why_elect: I was previously an elected Councillor for Raglan on the Waikato District Council. This has given me some experience with politics and administration. I have also worked with disabled people for the last 25 years and have a wealth of knowledge in this area.
candidates.why_stand: Rotorua is a good place to live. The gardens are amazing and there are good facilities for recreation. On the other hand I see people sleeping in cars and rents are very expensive, housing issues which lead to health issues. We need to solve these and other basic problems.

candidates.name: Tangihaere Macfarlane
candidates.why_elect: I'm totally fit for purpose having dedicated the last eighteen years to the health and disability sector. Nine years in governance and nine in management. Six years on a DHB advisory committee. I have a degree in health science, diploma in business. I am also a qualified health sector auditor.
candidates.why_stand: I was born into this wonderful community. I care for it immensely. It is diverse, vibrant and unique. The health sector is where I continue to concentrate my efforts. I'm keen to promote our health aspirations so we can be the best we can possibly be. We deserve nothing less.

candidates.name: Claire Mahon
candidates.why_elect: I am an international human rights lawyer with 20 years experience. I have held board appointments in community organisations, companies, and UN organisations. I have experience in multi-million dollar funds for global health. I have advised governments globally on managing health systems that are inclusive, just, affordable, and financially sound.
candidates.why_stand: I want to be able to help ensure everyone in Rotorua, Taupō, and throughout our district, has easy and affordable access to quality health care. I want to make a contribution to my home and it's people by building on my skill sets, my professional background, and life experience.

candidates.name: Liz McGrath
candidates.why_elect: I was educated in Rotorua and completed my degree in nursing at Waiariki. I then gained experience overseas and gained post graduate experience in Scotland and became manager for Royal College of Nursing, Scotland. On returning home to Rotorua I lectured in health at Toi Ohomai.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about healthcare and education and believe I have both experience and knowledge to make a difference.

candidates.name: Tracy Livingston
candidates.why_elect: I've spent decades as an osteopath, helping patients to heal themselves. My observation is that natural therapies can work alongside mainstream medicine to improve recovery times and reduce hospital readmissions. I would love to see our local hospitals integrate natural therapies so patients leave hospital healthier and more robust.
candidates.why_stand: I worry about the long term health of our nation. Our people are suffering chronic health problems that are often made worse with pharmaceuticals, instead of better. We need a new health perspective that incorporates the latest science and healing modalities to improve health outcomes for everyone. Better food education.

candidates.name: Ron Scott
candidates.why_elect: After the election half the Board will be new. We'll need to appoint a new CEO as the current CEO leaves soon. My nine years of experience on the Board will ensure stability. My background in economics, strategic planning and as a business owner are also valuable skills.
candidates.why_stand: Good health allows us to engage in the community. Getting a good start right from conception through to an active old age means that the community is vibrant. I have the skills and experience to help make that happen and want to be a part of the solution.

candidates.name: Bev Edlin
candidates.why_elect: I understand how the DHB operates, I sit on other Boards chairing a few, I care for people of all cultures and want to ensure we have the best health system available to those who need it. Living is about wellness not illness.
candidates.why_stand: After sitting on the Board, four of its committees and representing it on two of Lakes DHB committees I believe I have the knowledge, know-how, drive and passion to ensure we all receive the best care possible.

candidates.name: Malcolm Whitaker
candidates.why_elect: Because i have worked in Complementary medicine for 40 years. I eat a whole food healthy diet. Walk the beach twice daily. Do Yoga and Tai chi. Ride a bike frequently, swim several times in the summer. I "Walk The Talk " I will work to implement health programs as well as improving the Hospital Care.
candidates.why_stand: When I look at NZ figures for Obesity, Diabetes, heart problems, bowel problems and Cancers. We are failing to deliver effective preventative programs. I would like to see more of these, that focus on a healthier diet, exercise, dental health. Otherwise 10-20 hence we will be inundated with sick unwell people.

candidates.name: Geoff Esterman
candidates.why_elect: As GP for over 20 years patients inform me daily how the health system works (or doesn't). I have been involved with health politics at a PHO and DHB level. Currently I chair the Hospital Advisory Committee and am the board representative on the Clinical Governance committee.
candidates.why_stand: I am seeking re- election—as I feel as a GP that it is very important for the board to have input from a medical practitioner who understand the whole health system—and fully understands the needs of patients and can advocate for them.

candidates.name: Peter White
candidates.why_elect: I share similar principles as my late mum Jean White who served three terms on the DHB. I am a strong communicator and focused on issues that matter to people in my community. Māori health, care of the elderly and those suffering mental health issues are important to me.
candidates.why_stand: I was motivated to stand by an old friend of mine's poor experience waiting for a hip replacement. She was shunted from Tauranga to Whakatane Hospitals and left stressed by what happened. I have always been interested in medical matters—my favourite tv programme is 24 Hours in A+E.

candidates.affiliation: Driving Better Health Outcomes For All
candidates.name: Ian Finch
candidates.why_elect: Good Representation is only possible when the representative is listening to their community I consult, I listen, I empower and I am open to alternate solutions to difficult conundrums. In the end I am decisive. The bedrock of my personality are transparency honesty and integrity.
candidates.why_stand: Access to first class health care is a basic human right, I believe I can use my skills to achieve that goal in the BOP by becoming a member of BOPDHB. Enabling community to direct the way in which that is achieved is a major focus.

candidates.name: Clare Wilson
candidates.why_elect: I have been embedded in the BOP community for many years, working in both hospital- and community-based health and education services. As a parent I have been involved in sport and recreation, and have served time on the Child Cancer Foundation, the Toxic Agrichemicals Advisory Forum and other local committees.
candidates.why_stand: The Bay of Plenty comprises growing, vibrant, multicultural communities. I work primarily with young people and want to ensure they have access to the health services they need to thrive. My working knowledge of the challenges faced in these communities gives me a unique perspective to bring to the position.

candidates.name: Sneha Gray
candidates.why_elect: I have a wealth of multinational and local experience that enables me to bring a fresh perspective towards healthcare governance in the Bay of Plenty. I am doing a doctorate in people, place and identity and have a passion to ensure we improve the quality of services to our people.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that the right to quality healthcare is essential to sustaining our identity. Our country is miles ahead of many others in regards to affordable healthcare. However, we have miles to go in providing healthcare services with dignity. I believe I can help us achieve this milestone.

candidates.name: Marion Guy
candidates.why_elect: I have been involved on a number of health related boards over the last 15 years so have a good understanding of what is required as an elected representative. As a nurse I work with a number of different groups so am connected to current issues requiring improvement.
candidates.why_stand: I am a registered nurse having worked in hospital and community. This gives me a good understanding of healthcare options. My experience enables me to participate well in discussions and make suggestions for improvements. I want to see more equable, affordable and accessible health care for all people.

candidates.name: Callum Hunter
candidates.why_elect: I've grown up in our community, been a high-user of the DHB's services, and gone on to start a successful career. I know through experience what it's like to be a patient, and the challenges faced by staff—so have the knowledge to speak for them.
candidates.why_stand: I believe the diversity of our community should be represented on the DHB, including younger and older community members, along with families, different ethnicities etc; and those representatives ought to be high-calibre candidates—which I believe I am.

candidates.affiliation: Driving Better Health Outcomes For All
candidates.name: Mawera Karetai
candidates.why_elect: My motivation is to be as useful as possible to our community, and to make my life count for something. I have a solid education that has been fully applied in a variety of contexts. I really do give a damn about the BOP and all our people.
candidates.why_stand: I have confidence that with some new representation on the DHB, we can drive better health outcomes across the Bay of Plenty. We have a good foundation, but there are significant gaps in services that need addressing. We need experienced governance and more strategic thinking on the board.

candidates.name: Chris King-Hazel
candidates.why_elect: I was born and raised in Whakatane and currently work for Whakatāne District Council, and previously managed its pensioner housing. I have more than 12 years' experience with the BOPDHB (mental and public health), CYFS, and Ngāti Awa Social Health Services. I am passionate about ensuring health equity for all.
candidates.why_stand: I want to ensure there is sufficient representation to promote equity of health services across all demographics in the Bay of Plenty. I have strong roots within the community and an empathy for those who struggle to be adequately served by that system.

candidates.name: Nicola McCartney
candidates.why_elect: I am experienced in leading organisational change with senior management teams and with health professionals and organisations in medication calculation competency. From a successful commercial and education background I have specific expertise in strategic leadership. I bring energy, solution-based thinking and good leadership practice for maximizing opportunities for success.
candidates.why_stand: My motivation is to be part of solutions in ensuring we get the best quality healthcare possible for Tairawhiti people at a time when we have increasing challenges with health, equity and funding issues.

candidates.name: Glenis Philip-Barbara
candidates.why_elect: I have a solid research background and a range of skills gathered over a long career in education and the public service. I am committed to working across the entire community to ensure we have a cohesive approach to lifting the wellbeing of our community.
candidates.why_stand: I love our place and have long held concerns about the inequity of the lived experience of the people of our community. I believe the DHB has a core role to play in lifting the wellbeing of every person who calls Tairāwhiti home.

candidates.name: Peeti Wainui Rauna
candidates.why_elect: A matured clinical and culturally appropriate RN; recent PhD Philosophy; Queen's Honours NZ Order of Merit; Gisborne Court Volunteer; and recipient of the prestigious Mārei Apa Kura Award MOH 2013 for Māori Health; engaging, advocating, clinical management with governance to embracing the Tairawhiti District Health Board's successful appointee.
candidates.why_stand: I believe my passionate interest in health and well-being can greatly benefit our region especially the high needs and population of tangata Māori. I can 'walk the talk' in Māori Health Providership of Tamariki Ora, Rangatahi Ora, Maatua Ora and Kaumatua Ora inclusive of GP and Community Outreach Health Services.

candidates.name: Meredith Akuhata-Brown
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Tairawhiti all my life and understand some of the key issues facing those that also live here. I am passionate about working towards solving inequalities and challenging some of the ongoing status quo thinking that exists.
candidates.why_stand: I have served a term already on the Health Board and have gained some valuable insights into the issues facing the DHB. I believe I have more to offer in this role and want to continue to add value to this governance board.

candidates.name: Tony Robinson
candidates.why_elect: I am Gisborne born and bred. I have 22 years experience as a lawyer/advocate. I have worked with people suffering from addiction my entire professional life. I'm a founding member of Tairawhiti Men Against Violence. I will bring intelligence, dedication, accountability, utmost integrity and an unwavering commitment to equality.
candidates.why_stand: I love our city and region, our amazing people and our stunning environment. Unfortunately the people of Tairawhiti suffer serious health challenges coupled with access and resourcing issues. We need strong, robust, effective and efficient health partnerships to deliver better and more equitable health outcomes for our community.

candidates.name: Clive Bibby
candidates.why_elect: I have lived and worked in a low decile rural community for the last 40 years. I understand the needs and aspirations of the local people. I understand how they may be encouraged to adopt life changing habits that will lessen their need to spend time with specialist care.
candidates.why_stand: I want to make a further contribution to the well being of my community and believe l have the experience necessary to guide the Board in their decision making process.

candidates.name: Tracey Clare
candidates.why_elect: I have honed my governance and financial skills during almost nine years serving on the boards of Gisborne Intermediate and Gisborne Boys High School. I strongly believe in advocating for all people and am an excellent communicator. I bring integrity, honesty and an absolute commitment to our community.
candidates.why_stand: Gisborne is proudly my hometown. Tairawhiti is an incredible region that faces serious health challenges. I believe new ideas and energy is needed if we are to improve people's health and well-being. I am committed to an open and accountable Health Board with greater communication and stronger community consultation.

candidates.name: Andy Cranston
candidates.why_elect: Gisborne is home and I am looking to make it a better place for my children and their children. I have served as a District Councillor and had various governance roles in Sport, nutrition, activity and education. I will engage my experience and work ethic to better our health statistics.
candidates.why_stand: I have been involved in governance in the sport, activity and educational sectors for years. I believe the experience and knowledge gained offers a good fit to the work of the DHB. I am dependable, available, hardworking and thorough and will do the background work to make the best decisions.

candidates.name: Josh Wharehinga
candidates.why_elect: I have a health related degree. I have worked in community and social services. I had a lower socioeconomic upbringing so I literally understand growing up in the bottom of the statistics. I want to bring all of my learned and experienced knowledge to the DHB table again.
candidates.why_stand: I'm so passionate about health in our region. I firmly believe that education and health can improve the lives of many, and Tairawhiti so needs our health stats lifted! We are at the bottom of the statistics and I want to work hard to close those stats.

candidates.name: Linda Jones
candidates.why_elect: I will make an excellent DHB member because I understand the difference between governance and management, I have a rational and pragmatic communication style, and I am fiscally responsible and literate. My personal health beliefs are holistic yet not incompatible with the DHBs more western and medical approach to health.
candidates.why_stand: My career is in health research, disseminating knowledge about health psychology and health promotion through lecturing and writing. I have recently returned to Taranaki so with a wealth of experience of service on boards and strategic governance groups, the DHB is the obvious way to contribute to my chosen community.

candidates.name: Kevin Nielsen
candidates.why_elect: Taranaki born and bred with an extensive career in newspapers (36 years, 16 as general manager) and hospice palliative care (15 years as CEO). I am involved in the disability sector through conductive education and riding for the disabled. He tangata he tangata—it is people, it is people.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about our province and our people and will do all I can to ensure that our health services are universally available and are of the highest standard. We are geographically somewhat isolated and we need strong advocacy which I am determined to provide.

candidates.name: Graeme Hamilton Sykes
candidates.why_elect: Born in New Plymouth I've recently returned to support whānau. Through my family I have experienced the complexity of medical and mental health issues that stifle creativity and happiness. I have a broad commercial experience in business, local government, clubs and charitable trusts at operational and governance levels.
candidates.why_stand: I'm fundamentally interested in developing community well-being. I want to see the Healthcare Model broaden from emergency to early detection and intervention systems. This involves more understanding, funding and collaboration to meet our community health and wellness needs. I'm experienced in market analysis with the aim to improve services.

candidates.name: Harry Duynhoven
candidates.why_elect: My experience with central and local government, together with involvement in many Taranaki voluntary organisations is unique on the TDHB. All of my career has been working with and for people from all walks of life. I'm a good team member, with considerable energy, aiming to achieve agreed outcomes.
candidates.why_stand: I'm born and brought up in New Plymouth and have always been totally committed to Taranaki. During my career as MP for New Plymouth and as Mayor I helped many local people access health care. I believe everyone should have a fair deal and appropriate, timely, health care provision.

candidates.name: Bev Gibson
candidates.why_elect: I am an RN, have a Masters in Management. I have worked in primary, secondary and in community health. I am currently an ACC clinical cultural advisor promoting and supporting clients in their rehabilitation journey. I believe I can make a positive difference endorsed by 40 years in the health sector.
candidates.why_stand: I believe in high-quality health service delivery for all people of Taranaki. I am a advocate for quality early intervention and prevention programmes, promoting physical activity, and engaging in healthy lifestyle initiatives. These elements will minimise GP visits, hospital care and allow people to enjoy life to the fullest.

candidates.name: Claire Vogtherr
candidates.why_elect: While I have been in business for many years running Holly Bacon, I am at heart a nurse who trained in Hawkes Bay. I have governance experience so understand the responsibilities of this role and have the passion to robustly debate issues. A business head with a nurse's heart.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate Hawke's Bay. I want our residents to enjoy the best health and healthcare possible within the DHB budget while promoting community wellness programmes that ensure a healthier and more motivated school role, workforce and retired Hawke's Bay wide population. This will reduce admissions and improve general health.

candidates.name: James Crow
candidates.why_elect: I have 16 years of successful business experience. I bring strong governance and perspective to the role, sitting on both a company and charitable trust board. I will represent our community's voices while also ensuring the sustainability and economic balance of our DHB, and Te Tiriti O Waitangi commitments.
candidates.why_stand: As our community ages and our population of young families grows, we need systems in place to manage these diverse needs. I believe in developing a supportive and compassionate health system for our communities. To achieve this, we need all voices being heard, and board members to represent these views.

candidates.name: Jason Whaitiri
candidates.why_elect: I'm able to work alongside people with different backgrounds, voice concerns that need to be raised, be accountable for my decision's and able to manage matters that arise. I'm also not afraid to ask people working in the Health and Disability sector for guidance and solutions.
candidates.why_stand: I believe the DHB needs to reflect it's diverse communities to make better decisions that benefit all people whether you're under the Health and Disability Care, Primary/Secondary Care and Non-Profit Organisations. With the diversity across the DHB, I can see the benefits for the wider community.

candidates.name: David Davidson
candidates.why_elect: My governance experience includes local and national professional bodies, and previous terms on the board. I have also been active in service and recreational organisations. New technologies have immense benefits, but also risk reducing individual to statistics. We must ensure that the patient and family are our focus.
candidates.why_stand: I became the pioneer O&G specialist in HB and later a palliative care doctor. I have practiced in Palmerston North, Auckland, UK and Australia. My recent personal and family disabilities have highlighted the need for an experienced board advocate for the aged and infirm. I shall encourage a wrap-around service.

candidates.name: Julia Wilson
candidates.why_elect: I am a pharmacist and have an online business at www.discreetdelicates.shop that sells light bladder leakage underwear. I am passionate about preventative healthcare, and quality services for our ageing population. I was recently a volunteer member of the DHB Rheumatic Fever governance group.
candidates.why_stand: To ensure that Hawkes Bay has a high quality health system for our ageing population, that is also sustainable for future generations.

candidates.name: Peter Dunkerley
candidates.why_elect: I have been part of the delivery of a dependable, quality health service in Hawke's Bay for most of my career. I know and understand the patients and the health professionals. There are always difficult challenges. We have always got there with the resource available.
candidates.why_stand: Managing our health budget in Hawke's Bay needs a board with a complete understanding of the problems and challenges, and experience in managing the available and realistic solutions.

candidates.name: Trish Giddens
candidates.why_elect: I have worked 27 in hospital and health services.  My management experience is of 10 in health, 10 in social services and two in education. My governance is 20+ years—12 of these is local government, latterly as Mayor. I enjoy stakeholder and community engagement and working collaboratively.
candidates.why_stand: We have a great district and a growing population however people are having difficulty accessing health services. I've lived in CHB most of my life and enjoyed working and serving for the betterment of people and the community. Reflecting back 10 years and the current status of health—it's timely!

candidates.name: Leona Karauria
candidates.why_elect: I was born in Wairoa and i've seen a lot of struggling and challenges. My commitments have always been about the greater good for families and communities. Our many successes in community and technology mahi can be measured across the many communities across Aotearoa.
candidates.why_stand: The older I get, my health becomes more important and every time I lose a loved one, then life becomes that extra bit special. I want healthy families living in healthy communities.

candidates.name: Rizwaana (Riz) Latiff
candidates.why_elect: I started with the DHB, as an employee and branching into various other roles, which have included governance, project management and having an access agreement in the role of an LMC midwife. With 30 years experience I know how decisions made at board level can affect frontline staff.
candidates.why_stand: I have been involved with the Hawkes Bay DHB for many years and I believe that there needs to be a change how things are done. There needs to be a different approach and a more diverse range of members that are making decisions that affect a wide demography.

candidates.name: Graeme Norton
candidates.why_elect: I look for common ground on which to build trust and successful collaboration; respect and allow for differences of viewpoint, balancing that with the need to reach a decision; resolve issues and avoid being trapped by history; build better relationships with stakeholders; get difficult and complex stuff done.
candidates.why_stand: I firmly believe that we need to achieve equity in health for Māori as a priority. To do that we need to have concerted, collaborative action. A major reason I am standing is to bring my skills to the table to address these inequities which are unacceptable and avoidable.

candidates.name: Hayley Anderson
candidates.why_elect: I have real experience, in frontline nursing, and hospital operational and executive leadership. I have been CEO in primary care and GM in the disability sector. I have consulted to DHBs, Private Hospitals and Hospices. I was board member Hawkes Bay PHO and Chair Cranford Hospice Board.
candidates.why_stand: We live in a fabulous part of NZ but for many it can be difficult to enjoy what our region offers due to poor health. Everyone in HB should have good health yet we know the most vulnerable and Māori and Pasifika don't. I want to contribute to governance solutions.

candidates.name: Umang Patel
candidates.why_elect: I have been a Doctor on the front line for 15 years in NZ listening to patients across primary, secondary and rural interfaces and have seen directly the issues patients face. We must have a "health first" strategy and real clinical experience on the Board to achieve change.
candidates.why_stand: I want to improve the health and well being of all people in Hawkes Bay and reduce inequalities in health. I am motivated by the fact that we aren't delivering the patient oriented outcomes that matter the most. The ambulance at the bottom of the cliff approach is not working.

candidates.name: Ana Apatu
candidates.why_elect: My long-standing passion for health, along with my Bachelor of Nursing and Postgraduate Diploma in Public Health have led me to hold senior and national roles while retaining my focus on working with communities "at the grassroots" with programmes such as healthy eating. I am a champion for promoting wellness.
candidates.why_stand: Hawke's Bay deserves a health system where people are active partners in managing their own treatment and care. Communities must be supported to drive their own solutions, ensuring health resources reach those that need it the most and, in a way, that best works for people.

candidates.name: Paul Bebbington
candidates.why_elect: I believe my commercial background would add value to the Hawkes Bay District Health Board bringing new ideas and strong board governance. I hold Post Graduate qualifications in Business Management, Finance and Corporate Management along with a background in board level strategy in major international companies and government.
candidates.why_stand: As a survivor of Cancer I know the frustration and grief patients and their families go through due to inadequate services and lack of timely treatment. I will do my best at Board level to ensure that people have adequate and timely access to first rate cancer treatment.

candidates.name: John Smith
candidates.why_elect: Substantial submissions since 2011 on health related topics. Raw milk to then Food Safety Authority Health Select Committee on handing authority to fluoridate municipal water supplies to DHBs and Mental Health Inquiry. Accessible on my website knowledgewagon.nz Personally LCHF since 2002 living/loving the results.
candidates.why_stand: After 9 years since the Allan Smith story on 60 Minutes TV3 it was reasonable to expect DHBs to adopt IVC as common therapeutic practice. Beyond time it happened. I will be an advocate.

candidates.name: Garry Brian
candidates.why_elect: As a medical practitioner and eye surgeon, I have worked in NZ, Australia and many Asia-Pacific developing countries. I have held positions in international development organizations, including as Medical Director of the Fred Hollows Foundation in both NZ and Australia. I have experience and insight into community and hospital healthcare.
candidates.why_stand: I am not a single- or limited-issue candidate. My motivation is to see that best possible health outcomes are extracted from limited resources. If this is to be achieved, oversight of our health services by HBDHB must be evidence-based and dispassionate (but not uncaring). I will bring this to HBDHB.

candidates.name: Annette Brosnan
candidates.why_elect: I was raised and am now raising my family in Hawke's-Bay, I am extremely passionate about our-representation. I believe my assertive, well-researched and common scene contributions make a positive difference. I've also worked in Local-Government for 11 years and as a City Councillor, I also hold a Bachelor of Business Studies.
candidates.why_stand: I am running to represent us around the DHB table because there is work to be done, our struggle with resources, series of situations for improvement and poor health outcomes all need work. I love Hawke's Bay and believe I can make a difference for us.

candidates.name: Annette Main
candidates.why_elect: I have proven governance experience and a common-sense approach to problem-solving.
candidates.why_stand: I would like to see our community have the best opportunity for good health as possible within the constraints of our demographics. Whanganui has a good climate comparatively, with many opportunities for recreation.

candidates.name: Debra Smith
candidates.why_elect: I have a background as a clinical pharmacist and more recently as a mother of four children I have invested in whānau and community, where I developed skills in leadership, governance and strategy. These experiences offer a valuable perspective to the DHB.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that connected whānau/family with a strong identity and a sense of belonging are at the heart of wellbeing.

candidates.name: Philippa Baker-Hogan
candidates.why_elect: I've over 35 years of experience as a radiographer, working in our hospital or a Health Board member. I have overseen many challenges for our Health Board and Hospital and helped ensure its sustainability and safety and experience is vital in complex health services.
candidates.why_stand: I continue to believe the Health of the Whanganui community and a safe Hospital and Primary Health services are vital for our well-being and the sustainability and future of Whanganui. I commit to seeing improved Māori health outcomes, as this affects the wider health and social outcomes for us all.

candidates.name: James Barron
candidates.why_elect: I've have large project delivery experience with multiple corporate, local and central government entities. I deliver projects.
candidates.why_stand: I believe health is an integral part of community—both deriving from and building into good communities. Hospitals and healthcare are not a world apart but the foundation of vibrant, diverse Whanganui communities so I want to see healthcare delivered efficiently and well by using the communities knowledge.

candidates.name: Kiritahi Firmin
candidates.why_elect: I am born and bred Whanganui and I am a women who is a strong advocate for all people from all walks of life. I have a diverse wealth of knowledge in management, strategic thinking and governance. And I come from grassroots.
candidates.why_stand: We need to be colour brave and not colour blind! To include diversity. To encourage new thinking a the Board table.

candidates.name: Stuart Hylton
candidates.why_elect: As current Deputy Chair of the Whanganui District Health Board, I'm seeking re-election to ensure the momentum of the current Board continues. My experience and skills around the board table together with my commitment and energy will ensure the community's interests are well represented over the next three years.
